—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask: In view of the Government's failure to date to ensure fully the effectiveness of its invitation to United Kingdom and United States ships to participate in Australia's Bicentennial Naval Salute, will the Government reintroduce the Fraser Government's 1982 Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill, a Bill which received the public support of the current Defence Minister? Will the Government immediately reintroduce this legislation, which would give the Federal Government effective control over such visits and thus ensure that there was no repetition of last weekend's Melbourne situation, where Australia's defence policy was hijacked by the union movement with the passive support of the Socialist Left-controlled Victorian Cain Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point with regard to the superfluous ending of that question that the people of Victoria made a clear judgment as to whom they wanted to govern them. It is a pity that in what is a serious issue, which I concede, this nonsense has been appended to the end of the question. Let me put this issue in its appropriate context before going directly to the issues raised by the Leader of the Opposition. I remind him that the access that has effectively been provided so far in this matter is quite remarkable. There have been 30-plus ships in 12 ports in Australia in the last three to four weeks. On some five occasions there were refusals to cooperate but in those cases the ships were docked with the provision of assistance from the Royal Navy.
—Are you saying that it is all right if five do not dock?

—I intend to answer the question. If members of the Opposition will contain themselves they will get a full answer to the question. Those are the facts as to the extensive way in which a large number of ships have been able to participate in response to the invitation from the Commonwealth Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government deeply regrets the union action which has prevented certain ships from entering Australian ports, particularly in Melbourne. The action that has been taken is clearly contrary to Government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it?

—If the honourable member will contain himself he will get an answer which I know will not satisfy him. The ships will very likely be going into Adelaide. I know that upsets him but that is what is going to happen. We do not want to see this situation in the future and action will be taken to ensure that the Royal Australian Navy will have the capacity to deal with it should there be such a refusal in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: Now let me go to the specific question of Adelaide. What had looked like the refusal of the Seamen's Union of Australia to cooperate in Adelaide posed difficulties not only in regard to the visits of the ships themselves but also in terms of the added objectionable complication that Their Royal Highnesses the Duke and Duchess of York were on the Edinburgh and it looked as though, if the ship could not go in, the arrangements that had been made for the proposed royal visit to Adelaide would be aborted. In addition to our objection to the ships not being able to get in, that would have caused very considerable disappointment-to put it at the lowest-to tens of thousands of people in South Australia. In those circumstances, because we have been concerned with this matter, contact has been made with the Seamen's Union. What has been put to us is that in Adelaide there has been some-as the union put it-misunderstanding regarding the arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that honourable members opposite are disappointed that the visit will go ahead, causing them to make inane gurglings. I repeat that currently meetings are taking place and it is my firm hope and my expectation that the vessels will be able to go into Adelaide. I repeat that this must come as a very considerable disappointment to those on the other side of the House who would have hoped that the vessels could not go in there.

—Why didn't you say something.

TALK.START.PARA: —Failed. In this instance, in one instance, they failed. What we will do is bring forward--
—Order! The honourable member for Menzies will cease interjecting.

—I warn the honourable member for Menzies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security and concerns maintenance payments for children. Can the Minister inform the House of progress in ending one of the most shameful episodes in social policy history in Australia, that is, the difficulties for custodial parents in enforcing maintenance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all honourable members will recall the situation of the late 1970s when we had very low levels of maintenance being paid after marriage separation. There was no effective enforcement and less than 30 per cent of sole parents received any regular maintenance. During the period of the previous Government there was virtually no action. The only action of the conservatives was in fact to reactivate provisions to cancel pensions if action was not taken to initiate proceedings for maintenance. Of course, that action was futile. It was classic blame the victim stuff that put the sole parent through the hoops rather than putting responsibility where it really lay. As honourable members will recall, ex-nuptial children and step-children were not covered by a national law, thus creating immense difficulty in getting and enforcing orders and for the family law system.

ANSWER.PARA: The High Court of Australia ruled in 1976 that the Federal law only covered children of marriages. The Fraser Government commenced negotiations with the States in 1977 to try to sort out the situation. Of course, it is not irrelevant to the remarks of previous Ministers, including the Prime Minister, that while there was a great deal of talk during that period of cooperative federalism, there was no agreement with the States. Indeed, apart from huff and puff, effectively nothing happened during the seven years in which the current Opposition was in government. The present Government, operating not on the basis of seeking to blame the victims, not on the basis of seeking to put non-custodial parents in gaol as was suggested by Senator Durack, but on the basis of sensible discussion with the States, has now achieved a national approach. The Attorney-General got New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Queensland to refer the relevant powers. Last week Mr Berinson, the Attorney-General of Western Australia, introduced legislation to adopt the Child Support Act. Tomorrow I will introduce legislation to enable Queensland and Western Australia to adopt the Child Support Act. We will have a true national scheme for all children.

The area of child support is an extraordinarily sensitive area. It is a delicate area that needs some care. We now have a national scheme in place and we are beginning to see the value of a great deal of work done between the Commonwealth and the States and tremendous cooperation between the various departments of government. There is nothing more difficult in government, when one takes a complex and sensitive area such as child support, than trying to achieve a situation where the Attorney-General's Department, Treasury, particularly the Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security, work together to produce an integrated national child support scheme. The Child Support Agency is in place and is collecting thousands of orders not honoured for years. We have a real national scheme for all children with regular, monthly, secure maintenance. As I said, there is cooperation between the departments. I think that is a tribute to an approach to government based on consultation rather confrontation, on working together and on recognising that government involves essentially very hard work. That is the difference between the Government and the Opposition. The Opposition had seven years to sort out a problem. Admittedly it was a complex and sensitive problem. When it got to the end of the seven years, it did not have the problem sorted out. We have been in government for five years and we have a national scheme in place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Prime Minister been drawn to statements made by the South African Ambassador to a recent National Party of Australia conference? Can the Prime Minister inform the House of Australia's action on sanctions against South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The Ambassador for South Africa has been reported as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: The effect of the Australian sanctions on South African whites can be likened to an assault by a mosquito on an elephant.

If he wants to refer to South Africa as an elephant, that is all right by me. But let me say on this matter of sanctions that it is not a question of one mosquito. I will have something to say quickly about the degree of cooperation that there has been and the effect of these sanctions.

I want to preface this brief answer by reminding the House of the position of the Government on sanctions. As far as this Government is concerned, it would rather not have a situation in which one had to talk about sanctions. It has been put before that the concept of sanctions is not to bring South Africa to its knees, but to bring it to its senses. We would infinitely prefer a situation-I think the overwhelming majority of people in Australia would-where the regime in South Africa would come to the bargaining table, come to the negotiating table, because there is no virtue in sanctions as such. Sanctions have been contemplated by the world only in a situation in which there has been an intransigent refusal by the regime in South Africa to negotiate.

I remind the honourable member and the House, therefore, that it is not a question of Australia acting alone, but that Australia's actions in this regard have been associated with actions, as I think most honourable members would know, by other members of the Commonwealth, by the United States of America, by members of the European Community, and by others. Seen in this context, I believe that the actions have been effective. But more important than my belief that the sanctions have been effective are the statements that have been made from within South Africa itself. Statements by the South African Government and important actions by sections of the white South African community confirm the impression that I have had that the sanctions have been effective. In October 1987 the South African Minister for Finance, Du Plessis, said:
The negative effect that boycotts and sanctions have on the economy should not be under estimated.

Subsequently, South Africa's gold and foreign reserves have reportedly fallen by 28 per cent in United States dollar terms since December of 1987. I ask the honourable member and other members of the House to take note of these three statements from authorities within South Africa. The Executive Director of the Anglo-American Corporation has said that real growth in South Africa has ceased, investment has fallen, inflation has become endemic and capital cannot be obtained from abroad. Secondly, the Chairman of the Standard Bank, one of the largest banks in South Africa, has urged the South African Government and business leaders to push for an end to apartheid and to avoid increased sanctions thirdly, the Director-General of Finance has said that South African foreign currency levels have fallen to a `worrisome level'. In recent days we have seen President Botha visiting Switzerland on a mission specifically to raise capital in the light of South Africa's urgent need for foreign currency.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade Negotiations. The Minister has recently participated in a meeting of trade Ministers at Islamabad in Pakistan. I ask him how the outcome of this meeting will influence the Government's approach to the multilateral trade discussions due to be held in Montreal in December.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The meeting referred to by the honourable member was the most successful of the meetings of trade Ministers in the last 18 months because at that meeting the United States trade representative, Mr Clayton Yeutter, acknowledged that the Cairns Group proposal-a group that Australia has the honour of chairing-for reform in agriculture was now, as he said, in the ball park for agricultural reform. It should be said, for the benefit of honourable members, that the Government's trade policy has two fronts. Firstly, we continue to pursue all the important bilateral trade opportunities. There have been some great successes in that area. In particular, the Japan beef market opening was one of the most successful agreements concluded by any government in Australia-in stark contrast to the one which was negotiated by those opposite, who returned with an agreement for beef sales to Japan which discriminated against Australia. We had a good deal of success in removing from the United States Trade Bill those elements which directly affected Australia most adversely. Although the Trade Bill is still one which causes difficulties in trade, it is certainly a great deal better than the initial version. With New Zealand we have concluded a comprehensive agreement on closer economic relations-again, probably the most far-reaching trade agreement that any government in this country has concluded.

ANSWER.PARA: The second front, however, is the one referred to specifically by the honourable member for Burke-that is, the multilateral area. The Cairns Group is now recognised as a third force in the world agricultural debate. It is a group which has gained respect in the whole range of negotiations. We have also pursued all other areas in the round-not just agriculture, but areas such as services, the functioning of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade system, intellectual property rights and all the various areas across the range.

Nothing came out of the meeting in Islamabad to change the view that the primary objective of the Government should be to reform the multilateral system, because it is essential for small and medium sized countries such as Australia to have that system reformed. This Government has coordinated that approach across the board. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have used various international fora to put forward very strong views on the need to reform the trade system. Other senior Ministers, such as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, have put forward these views at every opportunity. In fact, it has been a very coordinated approach, which is in stark contrast to that of the Opposition. We have been waiting a long while to know what its attitude to trade is. In fact, I notice that on 11 May the Leader of the Opposition said that he would produce clear policy positions on all important issues by August-September this year. We are still waiting for the policies to which he referred.

The former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, did call for formal trading blocs in the Asia-Pacific area. That received some support from Opposition members, from the honourable member for North Sydney and the honourable member for Mayo. They obviously supported him in some way, as they called for a formal Asia-Pacific trade association to be established, whatever that may mean. The Leader of the Opposition, however, in his address to the Australian Investment Conference in New York, seemed to disagree with them. He said that when the Opposition finally produced this policy-and we still do not know what it is-it would call for the establishment of an informal trading association-again, whatever that may mean. The right honourable member for New England, the Leader of the National Party, is the official trade spokesman for the coalition. He has not clarified his position. Unusually, he is not a great supporter of our multilateral endeavours, because I recall that in this House he said that we should not blow out the candle on the multilateral negotiations; he said that it would take only a puff to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that this matter came up at a meeting of State and Federal Ministers for labour-in Sydney, as I remember. TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security advise the House as to the current status of the social security review? What is its role and what are its achievements to date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The social security review was established in February 1986 for the purpose of reviewing aspects of the social security system. They were very central aspects dealing with the issue of assistance to families, the question of income security and the labour market, and the area of retirement income. The review is headed up by Professor Cass from Sydney University. It is a review which has had a profound effect on government policy. It has now published five papers in the Issues Paper series and more than 40 background papers. Those papers have been very widely read.

ANSWER.PARA: The social security review has received more than 580 submissions from people interested in the various recommendations. The Government-this was not the case with previous reviews such as the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty of the early 1970s-has sought to address as far as possible within a quite difficult fiscal environment the recommendations that have come out of that review more or less within a year of those recommendations being received. Honourable members will know that many of the recommendations made in the first paper in relation to families have been adopted, with the result that very significant assistance has been given to low income families. It is also true that the Government has adopted many of the recommendations made in Issues Paper No. 3, which dealt with sole parent families, including recommendations with respect to the establishment of the child support scheme I referred to earlier. As a result of the adoption of those policies, tens of thousands of sole parents who were many dollars below the poverty line have been raised out of poverty by the Government's action in response to that part of the social security review.

This year the Government has announced two new programs-jobs, education and training and New-Start-which arose out of consideration of the Cass paper on sole parents, and Issues Paper No. 4, which dealt with unemployment benefit. Currently consultations are talking place nationally with respect to Issues Paper No. 5, which goes to the question of disability, particularly sickness benefit and invalid pension. It means that the Government might assist people who are suffering from various disabilities to get access to greater income, particularly through greater participation within the labour market. As honourable members will know, the social security review is about to publish a paper on retirement incomes. As a result of this very rational policy process--

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY REPORTING STAFF

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The growing concern among Australia's aged pensioners at their declining living standards.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In February this year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) met hundreds of pensioners at the front of the old Parliament House. On that occasion he was hissed and booed by the very same people who, over the last 5 1/2 years, have been told by this Government of compassion and concern that it intends to protect them. One may well ask why, if the Government has done such a wonderful job, the Prime Minister was hissed and booed. Why were these people anything but friendly to this southern gentleman who imagines that he can solve the problems of the world? The simple facts of the matter are that the Australian Labor Party's 1986 Budget decision to defer the consumer price index (CPI) adjustment to the pension by six weeks cost the average Australian taxpaying pensioner $70 per year. That decision was not the last in any respect. It is the basis upon which, ever since then, the pensioners of Australia have looked askance at the decisions, promises and commitments of this Administration.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the cost to the average pensioner was $70 per year as a result of that decision. The Prime Minister said that it was the Government's intention ultimately to restore the previous arrangements but not until it was economically responsible to do so. What the pensioners of Australia-over two million of them-are saying is simply this: `If you now have a $5.5 billion surplus, how much patience do you expect us to have? How much longer do you expect us to wait to get back to what we see as the deal entered into many years ago by which we were to receive full indexation?'. That was a commitment made by the previous Fraser Government. It is a commitment that has been fundamentally breached by this Hawke Labor Government.

The six-monthly delay in pension increases after the publication of the CPI has now gone from bad to worse. Not only has there been an erosion of pensioners' standards of living but also Labor's originally promised CPI adjustments have been delayed as long as two months. I am talking about people who are totally dependent on the pension. They are not rich people. They are not part pensioners. We are talking about people who have no other source of income except what they receive every fortnight. They simply cannot miss CPI increases for two months of the year and be told by this Government that somehow or other they are better off. What an absurdity! How could anybody make that suggestion?

The other day I received a letter, which I want to read to the House. It is a sad letter, but it demonstrates the heart-rending concern which millions of Australians feel about the pensioner situation in this society. It states:
Dear Sir,
I am appealing to you to try and do something to make life easier for myself and pensioners.

You already know, I hope, that we are forced to live below the poverty line. Clothes have gone up 30%-50% and shoes likewise. Food, as you must know, doesn't go up 2c but 20c and other household commodities the same.
I am a widow pensioner and have had to work hard full time to help my late husband make ends meet, and here I am in an affluent country having to plead my case . . .

I live in a bed-sitter and all I have in the world is what is in this one room, no car, no property to fall back on. Sir, would you like to live on a pension such as ours? (I doubt it). So please make your voice heard, and raise the pension to a livable wage and the ceiling rate.
She concluded:
Am I proud to be an Australian? No, sir; rather ashamed.
Yours, with disgust.

That is a sad letter. But I think those of us who were involved in a major meeting in Sydney a few weeks ago, which some 4,000 pensioners attended, received a more than clear message of the circumstances facing pensioners today. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) was, of course, not present. He was represented by the Acting Speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), on that occasion. The bottom line is this: pensioners are no longer prepared to provide support for a government which puts out publications such as Towards a Fairer Australia: Social Justice Budget Statement 1988-89. I draw this paper to the attention of the House. It states in the overview:
A cornerstone of the Government's philosophy is the achievement of a fair and just society . . .
Then it states:
In this year's Budget, the Government is building on its social justice achievements . . .

Tell that to the people of Australia! Tell that to the people of Oxley! Ask why they voted against the Government to an almost unprecedented extent recently. Ask the people of Port Adelaide or of any Federal electorate who have had the opportunity to cast their judgment on the Government why that judgment has been thumbs down every time.

Today we are facing a situation of critical importance. Older Australians have two fundamental fears. The first is for their health and the second is for their capacity to protect their income in retirement. Why do they have those fears? They do not trust this Government, they do not trust the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and they do not trust any Labor member on that side of the House, because they know that in the final analysis they will not live up to their word. In the last Budget we were told how the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was going to cut the price of beer. In that cynical effort he very effectively reduced the CPI. But we know that the CPI is the basis for the trigger for increases in the pension-those increases which pensioners have not been receiving under this Labor Government. Why did the Government not reduce the price of fuel? Why did it not do something to help the pensioners, by enabling those who have vehicles to pay for their petrol and transport themselves cheaply? Instead of that, in this cynical effort, the Government simply reduced the price of beer. It did not help the pensioners and it certainly did not help the economy.

We were told by the Treasurer in his historic Budget Speech-honourable members will recall the words `bringing home the bacon'-that, `By setting better priorities, the groups deserving of greatest financial support are receiving it'. It is more than clear that over two million Australian pensioners do not believe that they are receiving very much at all from this Government. I have no doubt that every member on the Government side, and certainly my colleagues, would agree with me when I say that none of them would have met one pensioner who has said he is better off today than he was five years ago.
Opposition members-None.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely, none; not one. The amazing thing is that in February of this year the Prime Minister, in front of Parliament House, said to the people, `Do not worry. I get letters from pensioners telling me how good I am. I get letters saying what a wonderful government I have and I get letters saying, ``Thank you Bob for what you have done for us pensioners''.' Heavens sake! Whom does he believe-himself? Quite obviously he does because clearly nobody else believes him.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a critical problem throughout our society. In the last Budget we were told, with much fanfare, that next year, 1989, those who cannot find a house to live in-those who are dependent on renting, who are at the very bottom of the socio-economic table and who are looking for somewhere to live and in places such as Sydney and Melbourne are required to pay massive rents-will get a grand increase of $5 a week. This will not happen in this financial year, not next month, but next year-but that is not what the Government told the pensioners. The implication of its marvellous advertising was that the pensioners would get help from this munificent Government and that they would get it now. What rubbish! Thousands upon thousands of pensioners simply do not believe this Government any more. This Hawke Government is a cracked vessel waiting to be smashed by the wrath of the Australian people. It will go down in history as the greatest `might have been' government of this century because that is all it is-a might have been government which might be able to produce the great tax cuts that were promised for the middle of next year.

We have already seen Minister after Minister standing back from what was obviously a commitment that should never have been made 12 months in advance. But those hundreds of thousands of pensioners, many of whom are taxpayers and many of whom desperately want reduced taxes so that they can live on their slender incomes, are now wondering what the future holds for 1989. Well may they ask and well may we, in response, say, `It is your duty to deliver the commitments that you have made and it is quite clear that you will not do so'. This situation has been reached because, for too long, we have had a Prime Minister who honestly believes in his omnipotence. He believe that the sun, the moon and the stars stand still because Bob Hawke passes by or, may I say, floats by on his cloud of make believe. What do we see today: constant changes to the income test-the most important key of all for people to have access to the pension. There have been seven changes in four years-March 1985, April 1985, September 1987, January 1988, May 1988, August 1988, and September 1988. Not being satisfied with that, the Government has also made sure that it has ripped the very last cent out of people who are trying to maintain independence prior to their retirement so that when they are retired they will have some money to be able to say, `We don't need a socialist Labor government to tell us how we are going to live'. What has the Government done to them? It has introduced 20 changes in superannuation; it has not created a viable retirement incomes policy; it has milked the superannuation system for all it can get. It wants revenue, revenue and more revenue.

Is it any wonder that the other day in the Melbourne Herald we saw a whole page advertisement with a heading `Wanted', followed by photographs of Mr Keating and Mr Hawke, the men who break their promises to the Australian people; the men who will never keep the commitments on which they were elected in the first place. They are the tax cheats of Australia as that article so aptly pointed out. The simple fact is that pensioners with as little as $15,000 in managed securities have also been the subject of the attacks of this Government in the last Budget and we wonder why they are concerned about their financial security. We wonder why pensioners across Australia are in revolt.

The time has come when many members of this Government, in marginal seats across the nation, will lose their seats at the next election. No longer will the hundreds of thousands of Australian pensioners be prepared to support the commitments and the broken promises of this Government. This was a cynical and ill-conceived Budget decision. It demonstrated Labor's growing contempt for pensioners who have tried to provide for themselves in retirement. At the eleventh hour the Minister for Social Security changed his mind because he was scared of what would happen in the Victorian election, and rightly so. If the Government had got the same reaction from the pensioners of Victoria as we saw in Sydney, it would have been swept out bag and baggage and the pensioners would not have wanted to see it again.

Week after week we see more and more changes to the retirement arrangements of Australians, both those in the work force and those who have left the work force. But the saddest part of all is that those who are out of the work force should be encouraged to be as independent as they possibly can in their retirement. The Government has ripped that independence from them. It has put in place systems which are impossible to administer and which people no longer believe in, because they know that this is not a government of compassion and concern or a government that is caring about their welfare. This Government has grown arrogant, slothful and tired, and it is time that it went.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A matter of public importance is no substitute for reason; attitudes are no substitute for policy. What we have had from the Opposition simply reflects its absolute bankruptcy when it comes to developing a constructive thought about policy. When the Opposition was in government it could not achieve decent income standards for aged pensioners, for two quite fundamental reasons; firstly, it was not prepared to make the kinds of decisions to enable it to ration scarce social security dollars-it wasted those scarce dollars on millionaires-and, secondly, it had economic policies which deliberately created mass unemployment. A quarter of a million people were put out of work and forced to share the social security dollar with aged pensioners. Our policies have reversed that. It is important to recognise that in 1983 there were 44 social security recipients for every 100 people in employment. We have reduced that by almost 20 per cent, to 36 per cent, and the number is still falling. That is the real measure of the standards society is able to provide for its aged pensioners.

SPEECH.PARA: How dare the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) come into this House and talk about fear. Who has done more to create fear recently than the honourable member for Bradfield, in association with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)? They have gone around this country scaremongering, trying to excite and frighten people who never at any time were likely to be impacted by the measure to which the honourable member referred. Again, without any thought and without any access to reasonable estimates, figures were pulled out of the air specifically for the purpose of frightening people. For example, on 28 August the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), asserted that tens of thousands of people would be affected. He cited a figure of 50,000. On 6 September he told Australian pensioners that possibly hundreds of thousands of pensioners stood to lose by that change. Again, on the same day, the honourable member for Kooyong asserted that up to 500,000 pensioners may be affected by some cut in their pensions or loss of their fringe benefits. That kind of scaremongering, that kind of appeal to fear and to emotion rather than to logic, has no basis in terms of attempting to develop a coherent retirement income policy.

Honourable members should recall that when we came to office aged pensioners with no other incomes were amongst the poorest groups in our society. In March 1983 a single pensioner was $6.55 per week below the Henderson poverty line. That compares with $14.25 above it now for a person in private rental accommodation. Married pensioner couples with no private incomes are now $44 above the Henderson poverty line. Since the Government came to office in March 1983 it has added to the age pension by $43 per week for single pensioners and $71 per week for couples-an increase in real terms of 8.2 per cent. This contrasts with a drop in real terms under the Liberal Government of 2.4 per cent-an increase of 8.2 per cent in real terms under this Government, as against a fall of 2.4 per cent in real terms under the previous Government.

The reason we need to develop a rational retirement income policy at this point in the history of this country is that people are looking for certainty in terms of that policy. People who are approaching old age are concerned that there be in place a policy which is properly balanced and which enables them to look forward with some security. As a nation we need to develop a policy which is not simply a short term and immediate response to current circumstances. We need to develop a policy which takes account of the fact that the Australian population is ageing. Whereas 10 per cent of the population is currently over the age of 65, when we get to the year 2011 something like 16 per cent of the population will be in that age group. So we need to manage a policy which provides adequate incomes for an ageing population. Of course, policy has to take account to some extent of current economic circumstances, although the fact of the matter is that this Government has achieved its goal of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We have maintained indexation despite all of the difficult circumstances that we face and we have sought at the same time to provide massive investment of funds in services for the aged through programs such as the home and community care program and through the restructuring of nursing homes. Generally, we have tried to provide a basis of long term planning for health care for the aged within this country.

We have fought long in terms of our policy but at the same time we have sought to maintain in real value and improve where possible the incomes of the aged. That has involved some difficult decisions from time to time, and when we have made those decisions the Opposition has been no help at all. I have to ask myself, because I certainly do not know the answer: What is the fundamental principle of the retirement income policy for the aged? It was good enough for the Leader of the Opposition to run down to Sydney and attend a meeting of Greypower for an opportunist whack at the Government over market-linked investment. It was good enough at that meeting to say, `Within a month I will be back announcing a retirement income policy'.

Of course, that policy has not been delivered, but I ask: Is it the Opposition's policy that there should be no means test in relation to pensions? Is the Opposition going to find the $3 billion a year that would be necessary to provide a universal age pension? Is that the Opposition's policy, or is the Opposition, like the Government, recognising the reason for targeting? If the Opposition recognises the need for targeting, is the Opposition-and this is still unresolved-going to disregard assets? Are we to go back to the situation prior to our return to government in 1983 when a millionaire or a person with hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of assets could get the full pension? Indeed, people were encouraged over the Opposition's seven years in government to invest their money in stock or in accounts that would produce no income at all, even though they were worth a million dollars. Is that the Opposition's policy? Has it a policy in relation to assets? It is good enough for those opposite to yabber away on the front bench, but I am asking a question to which I think the Australian people have a right to an answer. The Opposition has gone to two elections opportunistically refusing to acknowledge that issue.

This Government's policies in relation to retirement incomes have been clear. We have on the one hand sought to maintain the real value of pensions while reviewing the social security system through Professor Cass. On the other hand, we have recognised that much greater private provision will be needed in the future. This Government has taken the necessary steps to ensure that occupational superannuation is much more widely available than ever before in this country. Indeed, half of the work force now has access to occupational superannuation and it is estimated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions that under the Government's policy up to 80 per cent of the population will have access to superannuation by 1990. Our retirement income policy will not walk on one leg, but on two legs. On the one hand, it will provide support for occupational superannuation and for people to make self-provision and, on the other hand, there will be a recognition of the need to maintain and sustain the age pension.

When we have approached previous issues that have been addressed by the Government in the social security review, we have sought to address our policy in terms of several quite fundamental principles. We have certainly been concerned about the question of adequacy. I just wonder how concerned the honourable member for Bradfield is about adequacy, not for the minority, but for the vast majority of pensioners-perhaps two-thirds of pensioners-whose incomes are below the allowable threshold. How concerned is the Opposition about that? How much space will be given to that in the Opposition's retirement income policy?

When the honourable member for Bradfield talks about the problems associated with rent, to what extent can we expect that the Opposition, if it ever came to government, would do anything substantial to improve the incomes of aged people living alone or in private rental accommodation? One does not need to think for very long about its record to be very dubious about that. After all, when we came to government the level of rent assistance had reached only $10. That is the best that the previous Government could do. During its seven years in government the figure had reached $10. I ask the honourable member: What were the rents in Sydney in 1983? They were certainly pretty high then, and there were aged people then living in poverty. As I stated at the beginning of my remarks, people's incomes were $20 to $30 below the poverty line when we came to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. We got to $7 in 10 years. This Government has got to only $5 in 5 1/2 years.
—There is no point of order.

—The Opposition's record on the pension was built on the great achievements of the Whitlam Government. Historically, which government was it that raised the pension to an amount approaching the current levels and introduced indexation according to the consumer price index? Of course, it was the Whitlam Government that achieved that. During the term of the previous Government, what did we see? We saw a fall in real terms in the value of the pension and no substantial assistance provided to renters.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of this Government's record in relation to social security, we have had to do a number of things. First, we have had to tackle the massive and unbelievable problem of child poverty that exists in this country. Eight hundred thousand children-one child in every five children-live in poverty. That point is conceded by the honourable member for Bradfield. Secondly, we have had to tackle the problem of unemployment. We have sought to ensure that there are jobs. More than a million jobs have been created and there has been a reduction of about one-third in the number of people in receipt of the unemployment benefit. We have tackled the question of the dependency ratio of people of work force age. Who were the poor in the early 1970s? The poor were the aged. The government of the day addressed that problem. In the 1980s the problem of poverty has been essentially concentrated amongst people of work force age who were thrown out of work by the policies of the Fraser Government.

In regard to the social security review, we have now reached the point of considering retirement incomes. We recognise that amongst the aged there are some very real needs which were not elaborated at all by the honourable member for Bradfield. There is, for example, the problem of very old people living alone. With a growing proportion of the population living to their 70s, 80s and 90s, we need to think about what that means for income security. That is one of the reasons why I am concerned about early retirement. We have to think of people who are living alone and the special needs of such people.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the ACTU do?

—I did not interrupt the honourable member. We need to look after people who have no other income; people who have simply not had the opportunity to save or to pick up occupational superannuation; and ask ourselves about the relationship between the single and the married rate of pension. I would be the first to concede that it is not easy for a single age pensioner to live on $120 a week. That raises the question of the adequacy of the single rate. What is the Opposition's policy on the single rate?

SPEECH.PARA: One can go on and talk about the needs of people who have made some self-provision and what interaction there should be between the income test and the treatment of taxation, and the question of effective marginal tax rates, in which we invested $200m following the Tax Summit of 1985 to try to address that problem.

The Opposition can make its choice. It can run around the country scaremongering at the few meetings it is ever invited to, or it can join in a much more responsible course of building a long term retirement income policy for this country. I hope it chooses the latter course, because I think the first course is not in the interests not just of this Government but of an ageing Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second and support the matter of public importance before the House. I do not suppose that there would be a more important issue in the minds of such a majority of the people of Australia as the concern by the aged pensioners as to their future, their present situation and, basically, their concern as to where this Government will take them. It was not very long ago that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in the by-election campaign for Oxley that the standard of living of all Australians has been reduced. The standard of living of our aged pensioner folk and pensioners generally has been reduced by this Government. This is the same Prime Minister who said to the people of Australia that there would be no poverty in Australia within a couple of years. That was some months ago, if not a year ago. But the Prime Minister says to the same people, in a by-election, that the standard of living of Australians has fallen. He contradicts himself.

SPEECH.PARA: Repeatedly this Prime Minister and the Government contradict themselves on important personal issues affecting a great majority of Australian people. This has not been mentioned within this debate, but the thing I find concerning to the aged today is the fact that they have to worry that somebody will tinker with their returns or their concessions, their pharmaceutical goods, their hospitalisations and their housing-little things that to them are so very important. I, at my age, do not want to face the time when I reach retirement and feel that somebody will play about with my superannuation or my pension or something else, to take it away.

There are certain things that aged people require. Housing is one of them; health is another; financial stability is another; but the fourth and most important issue is less stress. I am talking about stress upon aged people. If they do not have stress, they will predictably have reasonably good health. It concerns them that they have to go along and talk to their members of parliament about it and say that they wonder what this Budget will contain so far as aged pensioners are concerned. There is no predictability so far as this Government is concerned on this matter because the promises it makes are not maintained, and this, in turn, actually affects the aged.

I stress that my concern for the people I represent and every honourable member of this House represents is the great strain and stress that the aged pensioner has today. Whether sick or in good health, they have this stress that the government, whether a Labor or coalition government, will do something to affect their actual stability throughout the rest of their lives.

Inflation has been a factor. There are approximately 1.322 million aged pensioners within Australia. The inflationary trend and other factors generally have not been updated to cope with their increased cost of living. Honourable members should go into the K-Marts and the market stores nowadays and see weekly the increases in the price of basic foods that the aged pensioners have to buy. They should look at the jam and the bread and the vegetables. No matter what it is, pensioners have to fork out more money to live. That is the important thing. They are very conscious of all these additional costs they have to bear.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said that by the end of this financial year the inflationary trend will be reduced to 4.5 per cent. How can he say that when our balance of trade has reached a situation where the Government may not be able to deliver the tax concessions it promised? That is already becoming apparent. The Prime Minister, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Treasurer are making public statements contradicting each other, saying that they may not be able to meet this great concession in taxation that the Australian people have waited for.

We talk about housing for the aged. At the moment 60,000 Australians are waiting for public housing. Let us consider the deeds of the Government. What about the capital gains tax? The Government says, `That is a wonderful thing; that does not affect the average working man and the pensioner folk'. That is why people are paying bigger rentals, I say to the Minister. If he puts on a capital gains tax, the person who invests in a unit or a home for the aged is going to pass it on. It is business to pass it on. If they could not do that, people would not be prepared to invest in projects such as housing for aged people. The Minister woke up when the Government abolished negative gearing. The Treasurer woke up to it. We repeatedly warned the Treasurer and the Government that if negative gearing was not abolished it would force up rentals for aged pensioners and young families in the community.

I was talking to the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) a while ago about nursing homes. For three years after 1983 I doubt whether there was a nursing home or hostel bed approved by the Government. Now there is a backlog in the provision of nursing home beds. Every community that we represent is ready to provide nursing home accommodation through Lions and Rotary clubs and the churches. They have the money in hand to go ahead and say to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), `Look here, we are ready to make a contribution'. Talking about capital gains, as the honourable member for Gwydir said, `If you purchase a unit in a retirement complex and then sell it you are up for capital gains tax'. The family home is not subject to capital gains tax. Why should a poor old person be up for that in the senior part of his life? The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, and the Government have imposed a capital gains tax on the person who has had the initiative to cater for his old age and has purchased a unit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you advocating it?

—I ask the Minister to promise this House that he will do something about it. I ask him to talk to his Treasurer about it. The Treasurer says that he is fixing up the loopholes. He is fixing them all right-on these types of people.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. On the question of relevance, is it National Party policy to have a capital gains tax on a family home?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Because my time is nearly up the Minister is trying to prevent me telling him a few facts about the way the Government is treating the aged people of Australia. Talking about nursing homes, I ask: What about the maintenance agreements? This Minister should ask the Minister for Community Services and Health whether the Government has arranged with the existing nursing homes what the maintenance subsidies are going to be. These people are waiting to find out, as are those who are waiting to build new ones. I have spoken already about health and I shall refer quickly to the need for a national superannuation scheme. What did the Treasurer do for the average Australian? I am not talking only about the disadvantaged pensioners, the 500,000 people who are solely dependent--
—Ha, ha!

—The Minister may laugh about this but it is no joke. He is having a cackle about it. Beyond the 550,000 who are directly dependent upon the pension, we have people who have paid taxes all their lives and have made an effort to put some money aside to help themselves. This is market invested money. As from 1 December the Government is going to take away any concessions that were given to them to invest and hold the value of their capital. This is absolutely scandalous. The Treasurer did not wake up to it. He was going to make it retrospective, but there was such a hue and cry from the community that he suddenly changed that requirement. But for the by-election in Oxley, it would never have been changed.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), knowing his generous nature, I thought he would have considered congratulating the Government on spending more money on programs such as the home and community care program or on the provision of hostel accommodation for the aged. I do not doubt that the honourable member for Lyne visits pensioners in his electorate. However, I doubt whether the same can be said for the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who represents the St Ives and north shore area of Sydney. I doubt whether he would mix with very many pensioners from working class backgrounds.
—He needs a street directory.
—As the honourable member for Macarthur interjects, he still needs a street directory because he continues to get Mount Druitt and Campbelltown mixed up.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to ask the honourable member to withdraw his comments about the honourable member for Bradfield. They were unnecessary. They were also outside Standing Orders and should be put only in a substantive motion. You should ask him to get on with debating the issue before the House.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I remind the House that the members of the Opposition who have brought on this debate today are the people who in 1972 under the McMahon Government gave Australian pensioners a 50c a week increase in their pension. These are the same people who in the Fraser years brought about a decline in pensioners' spending power. At the start of the Fraser years, when some honourable members opposite were in the Government, pensions stood at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. What was the level of pensions when they left government in 1983? Pensions had fallen from 25 per cent of average weekly earnings under the Whitlam Government to only 22.7 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that some people say, `Well, anyone can do anything with statistics', but they should ask pensioners what happened to them in the Fraser years. Their spending power declined from 25 per cent of average weekly earnings to 22.7 per cent. What did honourable members opposite do when they were on the Government benches and pensioners were screaming out for an increase in their pensions, because they were going backwards? Honourable members opposite sat on their hands and did nothing. Yet they have the hide to come into this chamber and say that we have done nothing for pensioners. This Government and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) have raised pensions from the 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings the Opposition left pensioners with to 24.8 per cent today. Honourable members opposite have the hide to say that pensioners are worse off then they were under the Fraser years!

I was interested in a statement by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who said that Australians had a fairly egalitarian society in the Fraser years: a fairly egalitarian society when pensioners had only 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings; a fairly egalitarian society when the Fraser Government was driving our economy into a recession, when the number of people who were unemployed was going through the roof. Honourable members opposite thought that was a fairly egalitarian society. I have news for them: the pensioners in my electorate do not think those opposite created a very egalitarian society at all. When I visit the combined pensioners associations in my electorate-in Toukley, Mannering Park, Gorokan and other areas-they do not tell me that they are worried about the assets test and the pensioners on the north shore who want to rort the incomes test. When I see pensioners in my electorate-a poor area-they tell me that what they are concerned about is that they start to pay tax after earning a very small amount of money. They are happy that this Government announced in the August Budget that it was increasing the pensioner tax rebate from $250 to $430. This Government does things while honourable members opposite just talk.

Pensioners also tell me that they are disturbed by the increasing number of pensioners who have to pay provisional tax. This Government did something about that in August. We ensured that any pensioner earning less than $10,000 a year will be exempt from provisional tax. What did those opposite do? Nothing. The provisional tax threshold did not change from 1966. Yet they come in here and say that this Government does not do anything about pensioners' concerns. They tell us that the big issue with pensioners is the assets test because they want their millionaire mates to get the pension again. That is what those opposite are concerned about. Pensioners in my electorate are not complaining about those with substantial assets no longer receiving a pension, because they know that if those people no longer receive a pension there will be more money for those in real need.

Honourable members opposite also tell us that they are against this Government's attempts to make the incomes test fairer. They think it is right that someone can invest hundreds of thousands of dollars into deferred annuities and different schemes to avoid the incomes test, yet pensioners who live in Long Jetty in my electorate start to lose part of their pension if they earn more than $40 a week interest on a bank account. How can that be fair? I accept that we must make sure that we do not make retrospective changes to the incomes test, but those opposite would rather have no incomes test at all. They want to give every person over the age of 65 a full pension. That would divert resources away from the poor pensioners who are really battling to those who do not need it-those who have hundreds of thousands of dollars in investments.

I disagree totally with the Opposition's attitude. Opposition members also complain that this Government has been too tough on the poor companies that are avoiding tax! They say that it is wrong for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to say that he will come down like a ton of bricks on tax avoiding companies. I can tell honourable members opposite that the pensioners I see at the combined pensioners associations in my electorate are right behind the Government in making sure that companies pay their fair share of tax. They are right behind the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, in making sure that companies cannot use rorts and loopholes.

It is interesting to look closely at the Opposition's policy on pensioners and government spending. It tells us that it wants to spend more on defence, that it wants to build more roads in National Party electorates, give more subsidies to farmers, cut petrol tax, slash income tax, scrap the assets test and abolish the fringe benefits tax. But the Opposition promises that pensioners will not be hit by a future Liberal Budget. It promises that pensioners will not lose automatic indexation, it promises that no pensioner will lose his or her fringe benefits: it crosses its heart and hopes to die that no pensioner will be badly affected by a future incoming Liberal government.

There was a similar promise from another Leader of the Opposition-Mr Nick Greiner in New South Wales. He gave a promise in the New South Wales election campaign earlier this year that, cross his heart and hope to die, no pensioner would be hit by increases in State charges and tax. State charges and taxes would not go up by more than the consumer price index rate, Mr Greiner said, crossing his heart and hoping to die. What has happened to New South Wales pensioners since the Liberal Government came to power? Suddenly the promises have been scrapped. Electricity charges have gone through the roof and pensioners pay 100 per cent more for their concession tickets to use the rail and bus networks. There have been increases in the cost of motor vehicle registration and drivers licences.

Also in New South Wales the automatic right of veterans to legal aid has been totally abolished. It is good to see the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) in the House. He knows that New South Wales veterans used to have the automatic right to obtain legal aid on matters affecting the Repatriation Commission. Those veterans no longer have the right to obtain that legal aid because Mr Dowd, the Liberal Attorney-General of New South Wales, sits on his hands while his State Legal Aid Commission imposes a new means test on veterans' rights to legal aid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keeping the half million dollars.

—Keeping the Federal Government's half a million dollars to provide that service, as the Minister suggests. New South Wales veterans are also pensioners. They find it difficult to make ends meet; yet the Liberal Government of New South Wales feels quite happy to scrap all its promises that veterans and pensioners will not be affected by Liberal spending cuts. As a result, in New South Wales promises are scrapped and thrown up like confetti.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter which might affect pensioners and which was mentioned by the honourable member for Lyne is the Liberal Party's health policy. The former Opposition spokesman on health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), wanted to bring in a system whereby pensioners were charged more for private health insurance than were healthy people such as those in the chamber at the moment. The Liberal policy is that pensioners and elderly people should pay more for private health insurance than do people of middle age. Honourable members opposite do not deny it. Sure, they have moved the honourable member for O'Connor on because they thought that there could have been a bit of community reaction to such a policy. Yet it still stands on the books. The Liberal Party's policy is that pensioners should pay more for private health insurance than middle aged Australians. It is hard enough for pensioners these days to obtain private hospital treatment, thanks to the efforts of the doctors and the specialists, which the Opposition support, in their attempts to sabotage Medicare. These people want pensioners who take out private health insurance to pay more than middle aged people. The pensioners of Australia can see through the Opposition's arguments. I am sure that they will continue to support this Government at every opportunity.

DEBATE.TITLE: STAGE 2 DEVELOPMENT OF RAAF BASE, TINDAL, NORTHERN TERRITORY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Stage 2 development of RAAF Base, Tindal, NT.

The proposed work now before the House is for additional facilities at Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Base, Tindal, as the second stage of a multistage plan to enhance the operation and support capabilities of the base. Tindal, 15 kilometres south-east of Katherine, is being developed as the major tactical fighter base in northern Australia and will be the main link in a chain of airfields across Australia's north which will be capable of supporting operations by Australian defence forces. Tindal will provide a home base for a squadron of the tactical fighter force equipped with the Hornet FA18 fighter aircraft.

Construction of stage 1 of the base is nearing completion. From later this year the base will have the minimum essential facilities to become operational for a squadron of Hornet aircraft. This stage 2 proposal involves the replacement of some interim stage 1 facilities and the provision of new technical and support facilities to augment those provided in the stage 1 development. Some additional on-base housing will be provided by the Defence Housing Authority to accommodate additional RAAF personnel associated with the stage 2 development. Subsequent stages of development of RAAF Base, Tindal, are proposed and planning is already under way. These further developments will allow the deployment to Tindal of other RAAF elements to supplement the Hornet squadron and enhance the operational and support capabilities of the base.

The proposed work in the stage 2 development includes extension of aircraft pavements; technical and support facilities, such as a general engineering workshop and an equipment warehouse; individual facilities with special requirements, such as ordinance preparation and storage facilities and an aviation fuel storage installation; community facilities, such as a chapel and additional recreation facilities; and the provision of 20 on-base married quarters by the Defence Housing Authority.

The estimated cost of this proposal as recommended by the Public Works Committee to the Parliament is $37.65m at December 1987 prices. This estimate comprises $34.9m for the base facilities and $2.75m for the on-base married quarters. This figure equates to $39.05m at September 1988 prices. Subject to parliamentary approval, it is intended that construction will commence in mid-1989 and be completed by early 1992. The on-site work force during construction is anticipated to peak at around 110 in mid-1990. I thank the Public Works Committee for its prompt consideration of and support for this proposal. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first thing to do when talking about Tindal is to remind the House and the people of Australia that the decision to establish a fighter base at Tindal was made by the Fraser Government--
—You will be supporting this motion then.

—Of course we will be supporting it. That decision was made by the Fraser Government when the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) was the Minister for Defence. It is not without interest that the current Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) keeps going around the place blowing his trumpet about how much he has moved to the north of Australia and about the fighter base at Tindal when he had absolutely nothing to do with the decision at all. It is also interesting to note that the present Government says that the abandonment of the aircraft carrier and the carrier force was a decision of the Fraser Government. That decision had nothing to do with the Fraser Government; it was made by this Government. I think it is worth putting those facts on the record to get them straight before we start.

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base at Tindal is a very important initiative in the north of Australia. Of course, we support stage 2 of the base. I was in Tindal recently and there is no doubt that the camp is being developed quite quickly and quite magnificently for that part of the world. It is a harsh environment which makes living conditions difficult. The RAAF should take pride in the spirit, morale and effort it is putting into developing that new base. One would like to say the same about the spirit of the Royal Australian Navy at the moment after that disgraceful and absolutely shameful episode in Melbourne in the last three days. The Government of this country turned its back on the allies that had come 12,000 miles at its invitation. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) is laughing. What did the Navy say about it?

TALK.START.PARA: —What's this got to do with Tindal?
—Order! We are dealing with a matter before the House which relates to the provision of works at Tindal. I ask the honourable member for McPherson to focus on that matter.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I acknowledge the correction. The RAAF deserves every congratulation for the effort it is putting into Tindal; it is quite magnificent. I say that because the RAAF-this is not a criticism of it-is more used to fairly comfortable bases. Members of the RAAF usually live in large static bases. For them to have gone bush, so to speak, I think has been something of a traumatic experience; but they have handled it very well.

SPEECH.PARA: The houses that have been built, and some more that will be built, under this proposal for Tindal are good. However, it is a great pity that for the want of, say, a couple more feet in the bedroom they are not made excellent. While the houses are good-service housing has been a disaster area for some years-here was a chance to do the right thing. The living room and kitchen are very good but if one tries to put two beds in the bedroom one can hardly move. It is a great pity that for want of just a couple of extra feet good houses have not been made excellent.

It is pleasing to see that some air-conditioning has been installed in these houses at Tindal. It is about time. I have said to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) before that the housing of service men and women in Darwin needs to be looked at critically because while some air-conditioning is slowly being put into some quarters-this is long overdue-there is no allowance for the very high cost of electricity in Darwin and a lot of service people simply cannot afford to turn the air conditioners on.

Tindal has become the home of 75 Squadron of the RAAF. The question that I wish to raise-it is raised in the Minister's brief-is this: Does he mean that 75 Squadron is now an operational squadron or does he mean that the Government is providing the facilities for an operational base? The Minister said in his speech:
From later this year the base will have the minimum essential facilities to become operational for a squadron of the Hornet aircraft.

I ask the Minister: Exactly what does that mean? Does it mean that later this year, at some unspecified time, we will have an operational squadron at Tindal? Is 75 Squadron operational or is the Minister providing an operational base for a squadron that one day may become operational? There is a world of difference. If the Minister is saying that 75 Squadron is now an operational squadron he is talking about a squadron with something like five aircraft and five pilots. The proper establishment for that squadron should be nearer to 20 aircraft and 16 to 20 pilots. I think that the Minister has tried in his speech-no doubt, written for him by someone else-to be very clever.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true, because he read it.

—He read it, but I doubt whether he wrote it. The Minister is being very clever. I think he is being too clever. Perhaps he would like to clarify at some stage whether 75 Squadron is operational or whether the Government is providing just an operational base.
—He could get up now to give us a clarification.

—Cut it out, he would need a couple of days at least to sort that one out. We welcome the approval of this work. We want to see it go ahead. The base at Tindal is in a very harsh environment. The service people there deserve good conditions. One day the Government, no matter which government it might be, will have to provide facilities to keep people at Tindal. Those facilities will have to be good. I suggest to the Minister that while the physical facilities are now adequate consideration will have to be given, when the Government runs out of the first batch of volunteers who go there and starts posting people in the normal course of their duties, to better conditions of service, extra leave and all that goes with living in a difficult environment. Certainly, we support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the opportunity to speak on this motion for approval of the stage 2 development of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Base, Tindal. I am very pleased at the efficiency of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works in being able to go through this expenditure item. I pay particular tribute to the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) for the expeditious way in which the matter was handled by his Committee. I will just make a remark about the contribution of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). I am a little surprised at the way in which he spoke about the FA18 Hornets. It seemed to me that in the first instance he was not quite sure whether he needed to dry dock them in Katherine or to fly them out of HMAS Coonawarra. Obviously, he has no clear understanding of the nature of defence facilities in the Northern Territory. That is clearly indicated by the ill-informed comments he recently made about the existence of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment and the proposal by the Federal Government to remove it to the Northern Territory by 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that the proposed expenditure on Tindal be seen in the context of the Government's overall defence strategy which includes, in part, as a result of the recommendations of the White Paper, the removal of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to Darwin. Unfortunately, as the honourable member for McPherson will now realise, his ill-founded and ill-informed remarks about the Government's position on this question have been condemned by all people who have any knowledge about defence matters in Australia and anyone with any credibility in looking at Australia's strategic policy. This proposal, I might add, is the result of a significant amount of work by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in forging a new link between the Federal Government and our defence forces and the way in which we treat them. It is understood by all in the defence forces that the work that is being done by the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) is unprecedented. This is demonstrated by the work they have done at Tindal. We have completed $240m worth of work. For the information of the honourable member, I understand that the cost of the removal of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to Darwin will be about $60m. Unfortunately, as I indicated previously, the honourable member for McPherson does not think there is a need to remove the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to Darwin, although everyone with any credibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. It does not worry me if the honourable member wants to go wandering all over the map on a subject on which you brought me to order, but he keeps repeating the point that I am opposed to the movement of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment to Darwin. The Opposition has never said that it is opposed to the movement of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment. That is the correction I want to make.
—The honourable member has clarified the position. I call the honourable member for the Northern Territory, who I know will stay within the subject under discussion.

—I certainly will. I was relating to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the removal of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment in the context of the Government's overall expenditure on defence matters in northern Australia. It is worth pointing out that on present predictions it is likely that by 1992 the Government will have spent more than $400m on Defence Force infrastructure in the Top End of Australia. That is to be applauded, as is the decision of the Government to proceed with stage 2 of Tindal. I am sure honourable members opposite know, this expenditure is for the construction of a further 20 on-base married quarters to add to the 379 already provided for Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) personnel on base and at Katherine under the stage 1 development. There will be new community and recreation facilities, such as a chapel, extended medical and dental facilities and new tennis courts.

SPEECH.PARA: These are important for a number of reasons, one of which was alluded to by the honourable member for McPherson, and that is because they provide adequate terms and conditions for the deployment of service personnel in northern Australia. It is important that the facilities that are available to them when they make that move are adequate and appropriate for their needs. It is also important in the context of the construction and other industries in northern Australia. Many direct benefits have flowed from the expenditure, and will flow from the proposed expenditure, by the Government in the area of Defence Force infrastructure in the Top End to the Northern Territory community. It should not take too much to work out the multiplier effects in terms of the construction industry in the Tindal area and in Katherine. By 1990 there will be a peak work force of about 110 involved in this expenditure, on top of the increase in employment as a result of the use of the initial expenditure of $240m for stage 1.

These benefits have been felt throughout the Katherine community which, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, is only a short distance from the Tindal base. Many of the Tindal personnel live in the Katherine community, and they are very fortunate to do so. I am gratified by the response of the Katherine community and its receptiveness to the defence forces' move to Tindal. They have demonstrated their desire not only to make the defence forces welcome but also to put pressure on this Government and the Northern Territory Government to ensure that the standard of services available in their town is commensurate with the demands on the community by a doubling of the population since the Tindal base was commenced.

I commend the motion to the House. Despite what the honourable member for McPherson has said and despite his views about defence strategy, it is extremely important that we maximise our defence presence in northern Australia. It is very important that we instil confidence in our Defence Force personnel, that we provide them with facilities that are commensurate to their needs and to the standards they expect.
