DEBATE.TITLE: NORTHERN COMMAND AND EASTERN REGION HEADQUARTERS OF THE AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Fitout works at 110 Goulburn Street, Sydney for the northern command and eastern region headquarters of the Australian Federal Police.

The proposal is to relocate various elements of the Northern Command and Eastern Region Headquarters of the Australian Federal Police into a single building. My Department, the Department of Administrative Services, has pre-committed a lease of a building under construction at 110 Goulburn Street, Sydney, for a period of 15 years with a further five-year option. The building is being constructed in accordance with the requirements of the Australian Federal Police and will provide 13,600 square metres of office space and 150 car parking spaces.

The fit-out of the building will provide: general office space to accommodate the various investigation units and support staff; general office space to accommodate the Northern Command and Eastern Region Administration; scientific/forensic examination facilities, and photographic processing areas; secure storage facilities; workshops; staff training facilities; pistol range; and staff amenities such as locker rooms, showers, exercise rooms and cafeteria. The base building is expected to be completed by January 1990, and the fit-out is $7.6m at August 1988 prices. I table drawings of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose this motion, but we would like to make a number of points about this project. I note that the fit-out costs for 110 Goulburn Street are to be $7.6m at August 1988 prices. I hope that inflation, particularly the inflation we now see in building costs in States such as New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia, will not add too drastically to that figure of $7.6m. It is a high figure and it is to the fact that it is to be spent on things such as providing general office space for the different categories of staff, workshops, a pistol range and staff amenities, that my attention is really drawn. One of the considerations with government buildings-this does not relate so much to the fit-out costs-is the question of their location. I notice that the location of this building is in Goulburn Street, Sydney. It is a leased building in an area of extraordinary high rentals. I hope that in the years ahead the Government will concentrate on trying to find cheaper areas in which to lease or rent buildings than has been the practice. I am not saying that is a practice that only Labor governments have indulged in, but I hope that as a matter of government policy, this Government will be concentrating on other parts of the city which will be cheaper than the central business district. Goulburn Street is in the central business district. No details are given as to the cost of the lease, but I do not doubt that it is extraordinarily high.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, $7.6m is very high, and one of the reasons why this figure is so high is the extraordinary restrictive work practices operating in the building and construction industry, particularly on government projects. It is estimated that restrictive work practices add about 20 per cent to the cost of government construction projects. If that is true in this case, the additional and unnecessary costs borne by taxpayers for the fit-out of this building will be in the vicinity of $1.5m. We really cannot continue to waste taxpayers' money on those sorts of restrictive work practices. The trouble with these Government projects-and I am making this speech in the greatest of all the Government's projects, the new Parliament House-as far as industrial relations is concerned is that they are pacesetters. The deals that were done with the building unions in this building of the new Parliament House spread right throughout the construction industry in the Australian Capital Territory.

My concern is that the Government is turning a blind eye to the same sorts of work practices in other States of Australia; it is spending taxpayers' money to support those restrictive work practices. It is my submission and the submission of this side of the Committee that that simply is not good enough. The Government ought to be using subcontractors much more extensively to do this sort of work. That is why construction costs for domestic housing in Australia are relatively low by international standards, yet it is the lack of subcontractors in the construction industry and the restrictive work practices that go with that, that explains why building costs are so enormously high.

To demonstrate my argument I only have to refer to the Ireland report on Improving Work Practices in the Australian Building Industry which was completed, I think, earlier this year. The Ireland report pointed out that construction costs in Australia were amongst the highest in the developed world. The Ireland report went on to say that there were two basic explanations for that: one, the restrictive work practices I have spoken about, and the other a series of strikes and stoppages. The stoppages, of course, still go on in the construction industry. We have stoppages when the wind rises beyond a certain level. The construction sites close down. We had a wonderful example of that in South Australia recently where a submarine construction site-at the moment the workers are constructing the site, not the submarines-was closed down for two days because it was windy. Union rules said that if the wind blew beyond a certain level the site should be closed whether the workers were protected from the wind or not.

Honourable members on the other side know about these sorts of restrictive work practices. They know it is true and they know it is outrageous but they also know that even if employees are working under cover on construction sites, the job stops for the rest of the day if it rains for half an hour or an hour. We, as a nation, cannot afford that and we cannot afford the tax bill. This is fit-out, of course, and rain, with a bit of luck, will not affect the fit-out work done on this site. But there is no doubt at all that it is these sorts of practices that make a project such as this-which, on the face of it is not a very grand project; as the diagram shows it is quite impressive but it is not a very grand building-incur a fit out cost of $7.6m. It is an enormous amount of money. I have not had time to calculate how many public houses, housing commission houses or housing department houses, could be built with that $7.6m but certainly quite a few. We will continue to monitor the costs of these sorts of building projects and we, on this side of the house, want the Government to do the same. We want it to take some action in the industrial relations area to ensure that those restrictive work practices that the Ireland report, I and so many people in Australia have referred to, are taken care of.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the speech I made on the immigration debate a couple of weeks ago I made the point that very few people who are opposed to discrimination understand why people are prejudiced. They assume that people made rational decisions about whom they like and whom they dislike. They assume that the answer to eliminating prejudice is to point out to people the error of their ways and that if they ask them to stop being prejudiced they will do so. They appeal to reason and if that fails they try to legislate to make it illegal to dislike people for no other reason than that they are different from them through their racial, national, religious or ethnic origin. If it were that easy there would be no such thing as prejudice or discrimination in our society today.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with prejudice is that it is not rational and that, while we should legislate to curb the worse excesses of prejudice and racial discrimination, we are not tackling the problem at its source. We are trying to find a cure by applying ointment after the disease has broken out. What we need is inoculation against prejudice and racism. We need first of all to understand that prejudice initially starts with human beings' basic fear of anything or anyone that is different. People feel uncomfortable, nervous, apprehensive, even frightened when they come across other people who are different to them. That difference may be merely in the way people dress, their accent, the food they eat, or their cultural or sporting interests. One only has to look at the brawls that break out at sporting contests to understand how easy differences can lead to emotional and often tragic outcomes.

Often, one only has to look at differences that exist within our own society between people of the same ethnic background, such as city and country people. People from the city who go to live in a country town are regarded with suspicion for a long time because they are different. They dress differently, they speak differently and they do not understand the mores of rural society. I am not saying that that necessarily breaks out in violence but we are all aware of the suspicion that the stranger is often greeted with. Those differences are much more marked when they are religious differences, when they are racial differences, when people are of a different coloured skin and when there are national differences. Then the degree of antagonism based mainly on a fear of the unknown can create quite extraordinary tensions which build into dislike, hatred and violence. We do not only have to look at our own society for God's sake: we can look at almost any society. Look at what is happening today in Yugoslavia between the different ethnic groups. Look at the hatreds that exist between the Kurds and the Turks; between the Iraqis and Syrians; between the Sunni and the Shiite Moslems; and between the north and south of Ireland.

One can go on for hours about these irrational and very often illogical deep-seated prejudices. I do not believe these differences and the tensions that flow from them are inherent in any of us. The evidence is that when children are placed together-people with different backgrounds; a different way of life-they are quite unaware of those differences. They mix beautifully together. What happens is that the parents pass on to their children their own deep-seated fears which they in turn inherited from their parents. I am not saying that that cycle is not and cannot be broken. Of course it is broken often. That is why I think we have a less prejudiced society today than we had 20 or 30 years ago. It is still there and it is still quite deep-seated in many of us. We do not even understand why we are prejudiced. We do not understand the basic fears that we have of other people with different lifestyles.

As I said, prejudice and discriminatory practices are passed on with the mother's milk. Attitudes towards an outsider, be he a person of a different religion, different nationality, different ethnic group or different coloured skin, are something one attains at the dinner table or at least among one's peer group. We will not change that pattern only by introducing legislation to ban it. I am strongly in favour of having legislation which restricts the worst excesses of racism. I think it is right to make it illegal for people to disseminate literature that foments racial hatred and can lead to racial violence. I take the view that we need a long term approach to eliminating prejudice from our society. By long term I mean 20, 30, 40 or 50 years. I have been saying this since I have been a member of this Parliament-nearly 20 years. It is a source of great disappointment to me that no government-the Whitlam Government, the Fraser Government or the Hawke Government-has understood what I am talking about. I hate to talk about forming new commissions or new committees, but I do think we need to establish either a committee of the Parliament or a committee of the nation to look at developing a program of combating prejudice and discrimination over the long term. I do not have a program, a format or a description with me as to precisely how it would work. That would develop if such a committee were formed. I have written to governments, I have asked questions in the House about it and I have been answered politely by Ministers and Prime Ministers. They have said, `Yes, fine; we understand the problem', but nothing really has been done about it. It will cost money-all these things cost money-but it would not be a lot of money. I believe that we need to look at the question earnestly if we are really serious about it.

I will concentrate on two areas. The first is schools. At the moment enthusiasm is waning because the heat has gone out of the debate of a few weeks ago-thank God!-but it will come again. We need to develop a program, starting in the schools, based on explaining to young school children the differences between people, why they are different and why we should understand, respect and cherish those differences. We need to look at the production of television films, help to break down barriers, concentrate on the things that unite us rather than divide us and pay particular attention to programs for the young.

Members of the media, who are often the first to take up the cudgels against those whom they accuse of racism-quite rightly-are often the most irresponsible in fostering and fomenting racism. Why is it that whenever a problem comes up they go and get Bruce Ruxton and Ron Casey to be the commentators? It is as if they somehow represent the only view in Australia on this question. Bruce Ruxton is Australia's answer to Alf Garnett. I do not think the British would consider that Alf Garnett was the spokesman on race relations in the United Kingdom. I recall not so long ago looking at a huge article in the Sydney Sun, which is extinct. It had a map of Sydney showing, marked in black, the ownership of property by Asians-not by the British or by Americans; only by Asians. We see headlines such as `Asians run amuck' and `Yugoslav runs amuck', but we do not see `White Anglo-Saxon Protestant kills a family of five'. That is the sort of thing we need to talk about to our media.

I suppose I am wasting my breath on this matter, but I hope that something will come out of a positive nature that we can develop over the next few years so that a real program to combat racism and racial discrimination exists in this country.

I am aware that the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) is going to address the immigration question. As I have indicated in my remarks, the honourable member for Robertson has already addressed the immigration question. SPEECH.PARA: I rose, not to enter into some sort of banter with the honourable member for Throsby, but to make the point that there are some basic differences between the way the coalition regards local government and the way the ALP regards it. I refer, once again, to the speech by the honourable member for Capricornia. In his concluding remarks-he was cut short by the clock-he referred to the number of local governing authorities within his electorate which represented but a few hundred people and for that reason ought to be amalgamated. My point is that local government recognition and representation on this side of the House, and the commitment of the Opposition to local government, has no resemblance to the size of a particular local government authority.

There is a general air about the ALP that all wisdom in governing matters rests with the Federal Parliament. We happen to believe that no unique authority is endowed on this chamber. We think that local government should be just that-local government. If a particular region-for example, the District Council of Minlaton in central Yorke Peninsula or the Corporation of Peterborough, to name two in my own electorate-has a particular characteristic that it wants to continue, a particular emphasis that it wants to cultivate, and if that is what the people of the region have democratically expressed as their wish, it should be free to do so.

We think that local government should reflect the needs, the demands, the creativity of a particular local government area. The responsibility of this chamber is to so redistribute funds that local communities have a chance to take advantage of the opportunities they wish to have. In reality, rates that are charged and paid to local government authorities are nothing more than a tax on productivity. We should be ensuring that we return to people as much of the tax that we have collected from them as is reasonably possible, to allow them to do the things they want to do in their own local area.

Let me illustrate some of the current responsibility that the local government is expected to pick up and for which it is frequently quite unremunerated. Mr Deputy Chairman, you yourself, in debating the matter of public importance this afternoon, referred to the health responsibility. Consider the health burden that is placed on country communities. A country community has a responsibility to maintain a hospital that can serve the needs of that community. But, more than maintain that hospital, in many instances that same community has been responsible for its establishment in the first place. Ratepayers have been the people to make the funds available. Yet currently under the Australian Labor Party, both federally and particularly in the State of South Australia, country hospitals-in my own electorate, the country hospitals in Blyth and Laura-are threatened with closure, not because local people are not prepared to pull their weight but because the Government has not been prepared to recognise the responsibility it has to rural communities.

I heard as you did, Mr Deputy Chairman, the cry of the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) during the discussion of the matter of public importance for some form of equity. `My pensioners', said the honourable member for Dobell, `welcome what this Government has done'. I tell honourable members that my pensioners in the electorate of Wakefield find themselves decidedly disadvantaged by what this Government has done in the area of health care and in the area of local government funding.

Let us look at some specific allocations of funds to local government under the Coalition Government and under the present Hawke Government. Total Commonwealth grants to local government in 1983-84 increased in real terms by 1.4 per cent and since then have decreased-in 1984-85 by 0.3 per cent, in 1985-86 by 7.1 per cent, and in 1987-88 by 0.7 per cent. Compare that with the fact that under the Fraser Government the total Commonwealth grants to local government effectively rose. Let us look also at general purpose assistance to local government. Under the Fraser Government general purpose assistance went up by 15.5 per cent. Under the present Government general purpose assistance has fallen by 0.3 per cent. What does that mean? That means that in local government regions and in areas as rural as mine, and yours, Mr Deputy Chairman, local people are effectively asked to carry more of the burden of achieving what they hope will be the local characteristic of their region.

Nowhere is this more clearly illustrated than in the whole question of road funding. Honourable members have heard me speak before about the stretch of road from Spalding Burough to Morgan, with which the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) is so familiar. TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the money going?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your interpretation.

Let me say to honourable members opposite who followed closely the recent Victorian election that they will be paying a very heavy electoral price for what happened. SPEECH.PARA: When the Leader of the Opposition announced in July of this year that the Opposition was going to drop its policy of multiculturalism, we looked forward to seeing in August at least the reasons for that. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take part in this debate on the estimates for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In the time that is available to me I would like to cover a number of matters. I would like to comment, firstly, on the need to distinguish between migrants and refugees; secondly, the need to attract more able, intelligent, adventurous, enthusiastic young migrants; thirdly, the need to review the family reunion element of our migration program; fourthly, the urgent need for this country to have a population policy; and, fifthly, the need for more children, rather than more migrants, although we need more of those, too.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn first to the question of migrants and refugees. I think it is important, when we look at our migration policy, that we clearly distinguish between those to whom we give permission to enter Australia on the ground that they are refugees and those who enter as migrants. Refugees are often people who have been discriminated against. They are people who have been driven out of their countries. They are people who, very often, are unable to return to the countries of their birth. They fall into a totally different and distinct category. We, as a nation, must play our proper role in helping to solve the problems of refugees that occur from time to time around the world.

I will briefly discuss my comment about the need to attract more young migrants. We often hear in relation to our migration program that one of the reasons for the desire of those who promote expanded migration is to try to make the country younger. For too long Australia has experienced what is described by some as a brain drain. Able, intelligent, adventurous young Australians have gone overseas, taking their skills with them, and have made great contributions to other countries. We still continue to provide a great opportunity for young people. It is my view that the current migration program is far too restrictive in the way in which it requires technical skills for people applying to enter Australia as independent migrants. We should be more adventurous in looking for the more adventurous. People who are young, who have tertiary education skills, who are enthusiastic, should be admitted because of their personalities as well as their paper qualifications. We should allow them to make a contribution to this country, whether or not there are identifiable jobs for them. We want young and enthusiastic people to come to what they may see as a frontier country.

I touch briefly, in the limited time available to me, on the family reunion program. I think we need to review this program. It was first instituted 25 or 35 years ago when our migrants arrived here after a five or six week sea journey, when the opportunities for migrants to return to their countries of origin to visit their parents, brothers, sisters and other members of their families were extraordinarily limited. We are now living in the jet age. We are living in an affluent age when migrants who come to this country have an opportunity to return to their countries of origin to visit their families and friends. After all, it is a long way from Adelaide, my home city, to Cairns. Many young South Australians live in Cairns, and their parents can visit them there, and vice versa.

I believe that migrants coming to this country from now on should be told if they are admitted for their personality, their enthusiasm, their skills or their education, it is they who are allowed to come and it does not provide an automatic right for them to nominate their extended families. In that way we can ensure that this country's migration program includes an even greater proportion of the young, enthusiastic and intelligent people, so that we can reverse the brain drain and draw from other countries.

I turn now to the question of migration policy as a whole. I do not believe that any migration policy should discriminate against its applicants on the basis of their race, colour, nationality, descent, national or ethnic origin, gender or religion. There is a need for boundary controls, though, as to the size of the program and the age, skills, education and personalities of the migrants; but there should not be discrimination on the basis of the criteria to which I have just referred.

Last week I spoke in this House about the need to improve the border monitoring and the need to improve the border controls on the migration of foreign capital to this country. The aim of this monitoring and these controls should be to ensure that too high a proportion of Australia is not owned or pledged as security to foreign investors and lenders, wherever they come from. There is a great difference between discriminating against people and discriminating against the country source of foreign investment and foreign loans.

Fifthly, I referred to the need for us to have a population policy. The recently announced Liberal-National parties' migration policy touched upon this question. There is a need for a greater emphasis by this Parliament, by all parties. We should be looking first at the needs of young Australians seeking to establish homes and a secure environment for raising children. Under the present system many barriers are raised against young families, and all our policies, especially our taxation policies, should be aimed at restoring a favourable climate for families. We need more children rather than more migrants. This is how Australia should be replacing its population and the way in which Australia should be keeping the average age of the population young.

Immigration, if relied upon, should be relied upon to the extent that it is in the national interest to increase our population. Before we concern ourselves with population increase, we should decide how we want to achieve population replacement. Experts are warning us of the implications of a less than zero rate of population growth. Headlines in the newspapers draw our attention to the fact that mums and dads are not producing enough children. We are experiencing a serious birth dearth, a birth shortage of major proportions.

This problem arises as a consequence of falling fertility. Australia's fertility rate is substantially below the replacement rate and below the rate required to keep the population stable over time. When one considers the dramatic effects that this can cause, one finds that a less than replacement rate means automatically an ageing population. I shall illustrate the implications that could face this country by drawing a comparison with the implications that currently face West Germany. West Germany today is on the course that yields fewer than 1.3 children per woman over the course of her lifetime. Recent demographic projections show that if that rate continues, it will reduce West Germany's population from 60 million today to 50 million by the year 2000 and down to 16 million by the end of next century. As one French Prime Minister has said, Europe, on that basis, is vanishing.

We are faced with the same problem in this country and there is a need for us to develop a population policy, to ask ourselves what are our population goals, what they should be, and whether there are institutional factors in our tax and social security programs that are denying young Australians the choice of the family size that they would desire. I am not suggesting that pro-natalist policies will necessarily encourage an increase in fertility, but I believe a large number of young Australians would desire to have a larger family if there were a less hostile tax system and a less hostile social security system, a system that recognised the cost of supporting dependants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few more comments, because I was cut off last time, in relation to the other aspect of Opposition policy which has had such an impact in this country. I refer to the way in which the whole concept of race has been introduced into immigration through that policy and through the debates surrounding that policy. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), who spoke previously, is to be exempted from this because he was one of those who walked out of the chamber. A number of Opposition members crossed the floor when we tried to reassert the principles of non-discrimination on the basis of race in immigration policy; but, disgracefully, the Opposition failed to support that because, obviously, it is involved in adopting a policy which contains those discriminatory principles. It is a sad day for Australia that we have had to have such a debate and that the debate is continuing because of the fact that the Opposition has not decided to adopt a new policy based on non-discrimination.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and others say when they talk to various migrant communities, they are not believed when they say that their policy is non-discriminatory. The reason is that it is in the policy. That is the problem. It is in the policy in terms of the following paragraph, paragraph 3, which reads:

The capacity of the Australian people to accept and absorb change must always be a main factor in immigration policy. The size and composition of our immigration policy should not jeopardise social cohesiveness and harmony within the Australian community.

Here we are introducing the notion that the composition of the immigration program is to be judged on the basis of some criterion of social cohesiveness. Here one has the introduction of two extremely dangerous concepts. Last night the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) said that there was no problem with social cohesiveness in Australia; it was just under pressure. If there is no problem, why has the Opposition introduced the issue of social cohesiveness? The honourable member for Adelaide and other members of the Opposition must ask themselves whether they really want to introduce these dangerous concepts into the immigration debate.

What is meant by social cohesiveness? Who is to judge it? Is it good for us if any person says, `I do not think a particular group is conducive to social cohesiveness', and therefore we have to listen to that group, or any individual who makes that claim? Imagine the dangerous consequences of this. This creates the very division that the Opposition claims it wants to get rid of, because allowance is made for groups of people to say that they do not like the behaviour of one group or another group. The very tolerance that has been built up through the multicultural policy becomes undermined and that becomes an excuse for saying that the composition of the program must be changed and there should be discrimination against people coming from certain parts of the world. That is the policy being adopted by the Opposition.

It is no use to run away and say that we are really not discriminatory or prejudiced. The Opposition has introduced these dangerous elements. As the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) said in his speech to this House, although some people suppose that a particular ethnic group, such as the Asian community-which in itself is a number of different cultures and different groups; but for this purpose let us talk about it-in some sense represents a problem for social cohesion, overwhelmingly the evidence is against them. What has the Opposition done? It has opened up a Pandora's box. It has discussed this issue. It has left the matter floating in its policy, and then it says that it is the Government that is creating problems in immigration policy. What nonsense! It is open to the Opposition to change that policy. Its leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who bears a great deal of responsibility for what has happened in this matter, will go down in history in a very dishonourable way because of it. The quicker the Opposition changes this policy, the quicker it moves back to a policy supporting multiculturalism and the idea of non-discrimination, the better it will be.

Yesterday the shadow Minister raised a number of other issues in relation to the immigration program. We are prepared to discuss all of those issues, but we cannot accept a situation where the Opposition adopts a morally bankrupt position as the starting point of its immigration policy. Once it gets away from that morally bankrupt position we can have a serious discussion about all kinds of issues in relation to immigration, including the administration of the immigration program. We are happy to do that, but we cannot do it in the context in which the Opposition has raised these issues, where it continues to persist with a discriminatory policy and to attack without justification and without any basis the policy of multiculturalism that has been a source of unity for this country, certainly not a source of division.

Finally, let me say one thing about the multicultural policy. It is no good spokesmen for the Opposition speaking at ethnic functions around Australia and then saying, `Why are they booing us? Why are they telling us to sit down? Why are they telling us to shut up?'. The reason is clear. Those people see the Opposition as attacking their rights, taking away the multicultural policy which has been the foundation on which we have based this general program of assistance and support to the various migrant groups in the community. It is no good the Opposition spokesmen going to these functions and pretending that they will be treated in the same way as before. Recently we heard the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) refer to the disgraceful attitude of the Opposition to immigration matters. The cowardice shown by the Federal Government in dealing with the unions last week in Melbourne in relation to the visit by the Ark Royal and the Fort Grange has brought great shame to this country. We have all been diminished as Australians by this dishonourable incident.

SPEECH.PARA: Page after page of the White Paper and Government policy statements month after month stress the importance of the alliances to this country and Australia's part in the Western Alliance. Page after page states that we are a staunch member of the Western Alliance and how reliable we are. Yet, last week ships that were invited by this country to come and visit for our bicentennial were left to wallow around Port Phillip Bay in indescribable weather without the Government lifting one single finger to help them. Not a finger! When the office of the Minister for Defence was asked what was being done about it, it was stated, `It is in the hands of the union'. The union has taken over. The unions of this country have taken over the control of our foreign affairs and defence policies. That is the reality of it.

If honourable members were to go now to the British High Commission or the American Embassy they would see that the subject exercising the minds of people in those places is how reliable this country is. Not a month ago the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said that it was time the American alliance was ended. Our allies are asking whether they are seeing the first signs of this country going down the New Zealand road. As honourable members opposite know, a matter of great concern to them is where we stand in regard to the Western Alliance. These people do not know who is running the country. They do not know whether it is John Halfpenny, who stands up in Melbourne and says, `We have had a great victory', because he and his mob have not allowed two visiting British warships to berth in Melbourne. Is that a great victory? It is a great and shameful disgrace.

Those ships were asked by the Australian Government and the Australian people to come here for our Bicentenary. One British ship arrived in Sydney with a damaged propeller. The British Government inquired whether, if that ship were to be docked for repairs, the Australian Government would allow it out of dry dock; whether the Government would guarantee that it would not sit in dry dock for weeks, perhaps months, because of industrial action? What did the Australian Government do? It said, `No, we will not give you that guarantee'. It would have been simple to do so because had the unions interfered the Navy would have been available to undock that ship. However, the Government would not give that guarantee and the British never made a formal request. What a way to treat allies and friends! So we had this disgraceful episode in Melbourne last weekend. Those ships left. We now have visiting British warships heading for Adelaide, where they are due the day after tomorrow. But already the Seamen's Union of Australia and the South Australian Trades and Labour Council in Adelaide have said, `We will not provide the tugs, any facilities or any services for those ships'. The British Government at least considered-I do not know whether it has reached a decision-not completing the bicentennial visit and taking its ships home. It was that threat of cancellation, plus an embarrassment that would be caused to the Duke of York, whose ship would have been affected, that at last got the Government off its tail to negotiate with the Seamen's Union. It did not say in here, `We are going to fix it; we are going to put naval tugs there; we are going to ensure that that ship is berthed. They are our friends, our allies and our visitors'. What did the Government say? It said, `We will try to fix it in Adelaide and we will negotiate with the unions'. When our alliances are in tatters and our friends are asking what sort of ally we are, the Government of this country is saying that it will negotiate with the unions.

I am, unfortunately, running out of time. If those negotiations are successful, do honourable members think that will solve the problem? What about the next time we get some visiting warships? Are we going to have the same problem? Will the Government try to fix the problem by negotiation? That is apparently how it is going to run its defence policy-by negotiation with the unions.

This whole matter has been a disgrace. The Government has to face up to the fact that it will have to legislate to ensure that warships visiting this country are given the protection they deserve. Once it does that, then we can start to repair some of the damage that has been done in the last week, and then we can again stand up like proud Australians.

You are to identify property holdings . . . which could be considered for disposal.

I would have assumed that the report would address this specific request by reporting to the Minister for Defence in such a way that he might readily and conveniently identify recommended property disposals-part of selling off the farm to pay for the enormous debt. SPEECH.PARA: It was a phoney piece of legislation in the sense that members of the present Opposition never had any intentions of enacting it-unless we opposed it, and then they could grandstand about it and make a political issue out of it. They wanted to make a political issue out of it because they knew that they were going to have an election. The old trick of members of the Opposition in every election is to try to drum up a foreign affairs and defence matter that they can beat the drum about. They have done it for 40 years now. But the Australian Labor Party fooled them. Members of the Labor Party said, `No, we will not oppose that'. So, it went through the House of Representatives quickly, got to the Senate and those opposite thought, `Damn it. What are we going to do now? They are going to support it. We cannot grandstand'. That is how phoney members of the Opposition are. That legislation sat there for three months.

They talk about aircraft carriers. The former Minister for Defence, the present Leader of the National Party of Australia and right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), already had canned that. It was about to be shoved in the closet. But, no, when we got into government and finally did away with the aircraft carrier submission, he raised it again and said, `Oh no, you should not have done that'. He had already decided to do exactly the same as the Government did a few months later, after the election.

I have a few quick comments on Australia's relationship with the South Pacific and Australia's defence cooperation program. Importantly, of the $60.2m in the Budget for the defence cooperation program, $45.5m is with Papua New Guinea (PNG) and the South Pacific countries. That is important because that is the most significant region from our viewpoint. It is interesting that $45.5m is being spent on the defence cooperation program.

As I said in discussing the foreign affairs portfolio estimates the other day, I have just come back from a trip to the South Pacific. I visited eight countries and saw a number of defence cooperation programs that are very well regarded and very successful. I think Australia does a magnificent job-it has some very good personnel in the Pacific-to achieve the aims of this Government and the Pacific nations which welcome the programs that we institute there. I saw some programs in Tonga which are working very well. We spoke to our defence person in Fiji and to people in a number of other countries. These are important programs. There is $45.5m worth of defence cooperation programs in PNG and the South Pacific-our most important region.

I refer honourable members also to a very important statement made in this House on 22 March this year by the Minister for Defence regarding defence policy and how that policy related to the South Pacific, our regional responsibility, our ships' visits, et cetera, which we are undertaking and which we have upgraded and substantially increased since we became the Government. We are the ones who have set out a program, not those opposite; they never did. We have implemented capital procurement, capability and cooperation with our Pacific neighbours. That is what it is about. The program has been set out by this Government and we will continue down that successful track.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we are discussing the appropriations for defence which, I am sure every Australian will be saddened or even horrified to hear, are at their lowest level for 40 years. Minister Beazley, like Minister Jones, is a Minister who I believe is totally committed to his portfolio and the thousands of people who serve under him. TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! You do not know how the Government operates.

—The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, who is assisting the Minister for Defence, is in the chamber. I would like to say the same about her: I think that she has quite a commitment to her portfolio. We get good vibes about her in different areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I revert to the Minister for Defence because he has the ultimate responsibility. He is virtually reduced to a `don't you worry about that' defence of the Government's cuts to his portfolio allocations. The lowest morale levels in the history of our armed forces and unequalled resignation rates or separation rates, as they are now called, now render our operational capacity doubtful. All the Minister can say is, `Don't worry about that'. As to the further extensions to the time limit for the introduction of new weapons and equipment, all the Minister can say is, `Don't worry about it'. The funding record for the past three years stands in complete contradiction to the Minister's own consultant's recommendations on funding self-reliance, and again we get the impression that we are not to worry about that. We live in an increasingly unstable and unpredictable region, and note the stepping up of diplomatic, economic and military competition in that region by the Soviet Union, China, Japan and Indonesia. Again we cannot help but get the feeling that we ought not to worry about it.

For all the success of the naval review-it was a great success, until Melbourne, of course-the Army tattoo, the air show, which was a magnificent spectacle for those who attended and The Bush Tucker Man, which I enjoyed immensely, and for all the residual respect for the Minister's personal capacity and commitment, the people of Australia are worried. They are worried because they heed the warnings of those veterans who experienced the needless losses which this country suffered in World War II because we were simply unprepared. They are worried because they heed the warning of recently retired and, indeed, serving servicemen and women, that, because of cuts and declining conditions, our defence capability must be seriously questioned. They are worried because the Minister's personal commitment does not seem to make any difference. It does not appear to carry any weight in the Cabinet.

It is the Minister's responsibility to submit appropriations which provide the security foundations both for short term contingencies and for potential long term threats. His reponsibility in 1988-given defence lead times-is to ensure that those who turn 18 in the year 2000 are not called upon to defend their country without the technology and the experienced service organisations to let them do the job. Unfortunately, it seems that this Government worships at the altars of the monthly opinion polls and the 18-month election cycle. It is therefore oblivious to the Minister's arguments for greater priority for military and strategic planning-and I am sure that he presents strong cases to it. As a result, we are ill-prepared for either low level but lengthy contingencies or long term security threats.

One of my fears is that the very success of the air show, the tattoo and the naval review will send the wrong message about the state of our defence in 1988 and will hide the morale problems of our servicemen and women. I take this opportunity to say to those who were so impressed with the public displays of expertise and commitment by the Royal Australian Navy, the Royal Australian Air Force and the Army that we face serious-indeed, dangerous-problems in defence. Talk to any serviceman or woman in private and that message will be confirmed. With each Budget we hope that the Minister will have come good, that he will have convinced Cabinet to put its money where its mouth is, that the funding will at least reach the minimum levels recommended so objectively by the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities. The appropriations before us reveal that we must go on hoping, because the Minister was betrayed by Cabinet once again in 1988.

Finally, I just say that I believe that the appropriations reveal very clearly that the only hope we have is that perhaps one day in the near future the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) will become the Minister for Defence within the next coalition government, hopefully at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —`The Australian people expect that Australia shall be able to defend itself. The Australian government accepts its duty to provide Australia with defence forces able to meet that expectation'. These words, written by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in his preface to the 1987 Defence White Paper, explain very simply the fundamental resolve of the Hawke Government to provide for the successful defence of this nation and its people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government, an authentic Australian Government, has continued to maintain the momentum of the 1987 Defence White Paper. In other words, this Budget is about re-arming Australia-to enable Australians to have the ability to defend themselves from their own resources and within the framework of Australia's defence alliances and agreements. Whilst the 1987 Defence White Paper provided a clear direction for the development of a force structure for the Australian Defence Force, this Budget, with purposeful resolve, is rapidly achieving the objectives of the 1987 Defence White Paper.

The total defence outlay in the 1988-89 Budget will be $7,658m-an increase of $236m or 3.2 per cent over that for 1987-88. One of the main priorities of the Budget will be to improve conditions, including housing, for service personnel and their families. On average, the outlay of $3,462m on Australian Defence Force personnel shows an increase slightly above 3 per cent covering the increase in service allowances awarded to the Australian Defence Force by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. In addition $60m is allocated, but not yet appropriated, to allow for projected increases in wages and salaries which may arise during the financial year. The Hawke Government will vigorously continue its priority to improve service accommodation for families and single personnel. Nearly $180m will be outlaid for defence housing this year. The allocation of $80m for investment on housing this year is part of the Hawke Government's pledge to spend $750m on improved housing stocks before January 1996.

The Defence Housing Authority commenced operations on 1 January 1988 as a government business enterprise responsible for construction, acquisition, leasing, refurbishment, maintenance and disposal of all defence housing. Under the energetic leadership of its General Manager, Bill Kirkby-Jones, the Authority is well set to achieve the Hawke Government's objective of providing good standard accommodation for service personnel and their families. Townsville is a major beneficiary of the housing program. This year the Defence Housing Authority proposes spending $4.7m on new housing construction and acquisitions in Townsville and Thuringowa in preparation for the move of Royal Australian Air Force No. 9 Squadron from Amberley to Townsville. The Budget also provides $11m on upgrading living-in accommodation. Work is already under way at Lavarack Barracks, Townsville, on upgrading 36 barrack buildings occupied by single service personnel. Refurbishment of the first barrack building is almost complete. The estimated cost of converting all 36 barrack buildings over a four-year period is $20m.

Spending on new equipment for the Australian Defence Force is maintained at high levels despite the tight controls on total outlays. This year 22.9 per cent of the Budget is appropriated on new equipment, which compares well with the 17.4 per cent of the 1982-83 Liberal-National Party Budget spent on capital equipment. This supports the Minister's claim that the economic need to secure fiscal objectives has not been achieved at the expense of the future capabilities of the Australian Defence Force. The extent of the program to re-equip the Australian Defence Force can be gauged by the fact that the total value of major capital equipment programs currently under way is $18,883m. Of this, a little over half, some $9,747m, has already been spent, leaving $9,086m to be funded over this and succeeding years. This does not include the costs of programs fundamental to the security of Australia such as the over-the-horizon radar system, follow-on minehunters and the Anzac ship project. One of the most important requirements for Australia's defence is to possess comprehensive intelligence about Australia's region of direct military interest.

A top priority of the Hawke Government has been project Jindalee-the installation of at least three operational over-the-horizon radars located in Western Australia, Alice Springs and north-eastern Queensland. This project, costing more than $500m, will enable the Defence Force to detect and track intruders in Australia's maritime approaches. Sites near Charters Towers and Hughenden in north Queensland are being considered as locations for the new radar system. The current estimates of the projects I have referred to would bring the cost of the re-equipment of the Australian Defence Force to approximately $13,250m-again emphasising the essential requirement that the Hawke Government continue its present high level of funding of capital equipment.

This Budget includes provision for continuing payments against projects approved in earlier years, including $402m for the purchase of additional FA18 Hornet aircraft; $53m for the construction of two guided missile FFG7 frigates; $381m for the construction stage of the new submarine project, the first submarine being due for delivery in 1995; $129m for 16 Sea Hawk helicopters to operate from the guided missile frigates; $65m for Raven field radios; $48m towards replacing the Army's Land Rovers and Landcruisers with 2,900 new vehicles, $30m for the Hamel 105-millimetre field-gun; and $27m towards the cost of replacing most of the Army's current small arms with modern weapons such as the locally made Steyr infantry rifle. One new major capital equipment purchase is for camouflage nets for use in northern Australia by the Operational Deployment Force and supporting units based at Lavarack Barracks, Townsville.

As with new equipment, the requirements for achieving a policy of self-reliance call for extensive expenditure on the development of facilities, especially in north Australia, which has been an area of defence requirement often ignored by previous governments. The value of the new works component of the facilities function of the Budget, which has been approved for 1988-89, is $291m, which brings the total value of the works program to $736m. Estimated expenditure in this area during the year is $372m, which will leave an ongoing program of $428m for future years.

A major component of the works program for 1988-89 is the further development of the Black Hawk helicopter facilities at Townsville. Many honourable members would be aware that the Hawke Government is purchasing 39 Sikorsky S70A9 Black Hawk battlefield helicopters to replace its existing Iroquois helicopter fleet. The Black Hawk is being acquired to meet specific army battlefield functions. Unlike other multi-role aircraft, the Black Hawk will operate solely within the ground warfare environment. Thirty Black Hawk helicopters will be based at Townsville. The two squadrons and supporting elements will be operated by 5 Aviation Regiment.

The Defence Budget provides for an increase in the active reserve forces to 30,880. The Army Reserve's 11 Brigade, based at Jezzine Barracks, Townsville, is part of the Early Deployment Force of the Australian Army combat forces. Under the leadership of Brigadier George Mansford, AM, and his extremely able assistant commander, Lieutenant Colonel Phillip Gould, 11 Brigade performs a vital role in surveillance activities in north-eastern Australia. It is the most combat effective Army Reserve brigade in the Australian Army Reserve. This defence budget proposes to enhance surveillance capabilities in northern Australia. This will enable 11 Brigade to continue expanding the numbers of active Army reservists and the scope of the activities conducted by the Brigade.

During the past 10 months, a brigade signals squadron, 140 Signals Squadron, has been raised with its headquarters in Townsville and troop sized detachments in Rockhampton and Cairns. This organisation is expanding rapidly and, subject to equipment availability, will provide communications throughout the 11 Brigade's area of operations by the end of 1988. An engineer field troop, a sub-unit of the Mount Isa based 35 Field Engineer Squadron, is shortly to be raised in Townsville. In addition, a recent affiliation between the Brisbane based 13 Field Battery, Royal Australian Artillery and 11 Brigade units has given 11 Brigade, for the first time, the capability to deploy field artillery in support of operations throughout northern Australia. Exercise Kangaroo 89, to be held in July-October 1989, will allow 11 Brigade to exercise this capability in the Weipa region.

High standards continue to be achieved in training, with short notice deployment exercises taking infantry company sized groups of the Brigade into the Cape York Peninsula to link up with Regional Force Surveillance Unit patrols of the Brigade's 51st Battalion, Far North Queensland Regiment, based at Cairns. These weekend activities familiarise soldiers of 11 Brigade with their intended area of operations and demonstrate that Reserve units can deploy rapidly into remote areas, given modest resources to do so.

The Australian defence forces are at their most combat ready in the history of our country. I know that, under the competent leadership of the Minister for Defence and with the commitment and will of the Hawke Labor Government, Australia, within the next few years, will build one of the most formidable defence forces in the South Pacific region. I would like to record the thanks of the nation to the Minister for Defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, from 12 October to 16 October inclusive, there was staged at the Royal Australian Air Force base at Richmond near Sydney the Bicentennial Air Show, which was jointly organised by Schofields Flying Club and the RAAF. Schofields Flying Club is a small private enterprise organisation based at the Schofields Aerodrome in north-west Sydney. That aerodrome is presently under threat of sale by the Department of Defence, as was stated in the recent Budget Papers.
—It should not be sold.

—It should not indeed. I put it to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) that Schofields Aerodrome is an irreplaceable community asset. The siting of a new aerodrome of this sort is about as popular as the siting of a new maximum security prison. It is imperative that New South Wales retain this aerodrome to cater for the progress of general aviation in Sydney and in New South Wales generally. Indeed, as Badgerys Creek proceeds as the site for the second Sydney airport, without Schofields Aerodrome the future of general aviation in Sydney and its environs would be impossible.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bicentennial Air Show was a magnificent affair, as my colleague the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) mentioned a moment ago. It was the largest and most complex air show ever staged in the Southern Hemisphere. The overall display area took up an area the size of the World Expo 88 site in Brisbane. Among many memorable flying displays, including those by the United Kingdom Harrier aircraft, the display by the RAAF FA18s was outstanding. Those aircraft, of course, were ordered by the previous Government. The Hornet demonstration, after a breathtaking display of speed, manoeuvrability and brute power, concluded with the aircraft climbing absolutely vertically, rotating slowly around that vertical axis until, at about 25,000 feet, it disappeared from sight. The obvious satisfaction and pride on the part of top Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel at acquiring this aircraft, with its state of the art technology-and their pride in the youthful Australian `top guns', if I might use that phrase, who put the aircraft through their paces-was very plain to see. It was clear to me as I attended the Air Show during the weekend.

But-and this is the point I am coming to-defence capability comprises equipment and operational abilities. No matter is more vital to the Australian Defence Force at present than to stop the debilitating personnel wastage that is undermining its operational effectiveness. The present Government has not adequately come to grips with this problem. There has been a record loss of personnel from the Defence Force and a resulting decline in the ADF's capability. Defence Force personnel are concerned about all aspects-pay, conditions of service, reduced manning levels, long hours of work, the need for a more purposeful and wider role for personnel, and disruptions to family life.

I am aware that the Minister is conscious of these difficulties. But of these matters that I have mentioned pay, as is the case for many of us, is the bottom line. In discussions that I have had with high ranking service officers and top businessmen, it has become very clear to me that the gap between service pay for high ranking officers with high level responsibilities and that for their civilian counterparts who have the same sorts of responsibilities, including the number of personnel under their control, responsibility for financial control and so on, is very large. In fact, the ratio of civilian pay to service pay could well be at least 3:1. That would exclude the periodic bonuses of six figures, or maybe even more, which can come the way of top civilian company personnel. I repeat this point: pay is the bottom line, although increased manning levels, better housing and other amenities and increased and broadened opportunities for training and operational experience are also important.

I would suggest to the Government that nothing short of a grasping of the nettle, Mrs Thatcher style, and a very substantial lift in higher middle to top ranking service salaries and allowances is necessary, and possibly tax free allowances would be about the most cost-effective way of doing it. Otherwise, one gets an inevitable plateauing effect which discourages middle ranking officers from persevering with a service career. Especially is all that true in areas where the cost of training runs into very large sums, hundreds of thousands of dollars, if not more. In those situations in particular it is not a case that the Government, in this defence vote, cannot afford the money-but, rather, that when due account is taken of the cost of training, the truth is that on a rational view the Government cannot afford not to lift salaries and thereby to arrest the loss of personnel that is threatening to undermine the operational effectiveness of the Australian defence forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for their contribution to this debate-in particular, the honourable members for Isaacs (Mr Charles) and Herbert (Mr Lindsay), and the honourable members for Macquarie (Mr Webster) and Berowra (Dr Edwards). I was a little disappointed with the contribution of the shadow defence Minister, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). It is appalling, and an indictment of his position on defence, that on one of the few occasions on which we have the opportunity for a debate on important issues of defence he comes into this chamber and does not discuss issues related to defence personnel or even to major issues of procurement policy. Instead of that, he brought up the issue of the ships' visit, which was covered in responses by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) during Question Time. That highlights his attitude to the important issue of defence personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I concede that that was not followed up by the other Opposition members, and I thank them for some of their comments, even though I do not agree with all of the points they raised; and I shall refer to those in a moment.

First, the Minister for Defence should be congratulated on the level of defence expenditure. In very difficult economic times, defence expenditure is $7.658 billion. That is an almost incredible amount of expenditure when one considers the tough economic times. We have 0.5 per cent growth in real terms. When looking at how that money is spent, I am pleased to see that a considerable proportion is spent on defence personnel. There was an increase from 40.8 per cent to 43 per cent from 1986-87 to 1987-88, and for 1988-89 it remains at 43 per cent-a very large increase.

Another area covered in the debate was the amount of money paid to defence service personnel. Expenditure on pay and allowances is estimated to increase by $64.1m, or 3 per cent, to over $2 billion, and this compares with an overall defence budget increase of 0.5 per cent, as I have stated. So I believe the balance is right. The Government has a very great difference from the Opposition in that we have an overall policy. We are directing our defence policy to the area that clearly needs expenditure, and that is obviously capital procurement, because of the terrific rundown in the coalition party years, but more importantly, we are putting important emphasis on the personnel side. That is not just about pay and allowances; it is also about lifestyle and about conditions under which people live, like their housing, and even things important to morale, such as equipment.

The Opposition does not have a policy on defence. The honourable member for Berowra talks about pay levels. I agree that there are problems about pay compression, particularly amongst our middle ranking officers. That is something that I am now looking at. However, on the other hand, our salary ranges cannot be compared with those in the private sector. It is just not possible. Consider the pilots, for example. How can we pay our pilots what pilots are being paid by Qantas? That is not on. I would be surprised if that was Opposition policy-but we do not know what Opposition policy is. The Opposition comes into this House and says that it wants cutbacks. Members of the Opposition criticise the Government for spending so much on major new works, but they do not give the Government any idea where they would make cuts. Instead, they say that they will not be specific about which programs they would cut. Are they planning to continue with the F18 program, to continue with the Black Hawks, and to continue with the submarine project? Or would the Opposition pull out? Members of the Opposition do not say what they would spend their money on. Occasionally they drop a good line by saying that they are investigating nuclear powered submarines and that that is a possibility. Then the subject of an aircraft carrier is raised again and floats through the chamber every few months. Members of the Opposition never think about where the money is to come from. The Government is urged to put more money into personnel, but what would the Opposition cut in order to do this?

Morale in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) is a balance between providing increases in salary and providing the equipment that is needed. At present the Navy's morale is very high. Among the reasons for that are the new submarines and the new frigate program. There is no point in having a navy without decent equipment. The same goes for the Royal Australian Air Force and the Army. That is the essential balance, and this Government has got the balance right. We do not know what the Opposition's balance is. The Opposition has never told us. All the Opposition says is that it wants more of this and more of that-and the sums never add up.

The Opposition's solution to the problem was to get another shadow Minister. I welcome Senator Newman to shadow me. But now I am pleased to know that I have two shadow spokesmen, because the shadow Minister for defence has hardly made a comment about defence in my 14 months in this job. Instead, he talks specifically about my side of the portfolio, the personnel; I have welcomed his comments. But now I have two shadowing me, and the Defence Minister seems to be left alone-probably because they know that they cannot get near him. The two shadow Ministers will be as ineffectual as each other because neither has enough status to be in the shadow Cabinet. I recognise that I have the humble role of being a junior Minister, but I work with the Minister for Defence, who is a very active member of the Cabinet and who usually wins his battle in the Cabinet. Here we have two of them-and two of them do not equal two of us on this side by any stretch of the imagination.

What is the Opposition policy? The Opposition does not have one. First we hear from the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who is followed by the honourable member for Berowra, and it is stated that the Opposition does not want anything sold. It wants to spend more money on defence. Everyone in the Opposition agrees that more money should be spent on defence-although I am not sure that the shadow Treasurer agrees with that. But, the Opposition states, nothing should be sold off. The honourable member for Warringah talked about his wonderful land in Sydney. It is beautiful land.

No decision has been taken on the report of the Cooksey review of Australia's defence facilities. Mr Cooksey looked at what our assets are. The Opposition policy was so hopeless when the parties opposite were in government that they did not even know what we had. The assets register is very useful just to see what defence facilities we have around this country. We shall have a look and ascertain how it fits in with our overall defence policy. That is all set out in the defence White Paper. Everything is in a context.

As far as land is concerned, I have my eyes on some of that land also, for defence housing. I want to see that land that is not used and is surplus to our requirements used for defence housing. That is a very important progress.

I take issue with the honourable member for Macquarie. I appreciated a lot of the points he made but some of the things he just got wrong, particularly his comments on operational readiness. This is probably the most important point that needs to be taken up today. The honourable member made a point about wastage rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the middle of celebration of the eighth anniversary of those who entered Parliament in 1980, which was disrupted by the quorum, I would like to thank the honourable member for Berowra and the honourable member for Macquarie for returning to the chamber to follow through the lecture I was giving them about defence policy. Though I do appreciate the interest and great understanding they showed in this debate-unlike the shadow Minister, who did not consider any of the issues relating to Defence Force personnel-they were misled on a couple of points. The particular point I was discussing with the honourable member for Macquarie before the Committee broke for dinner was the operational readiness of the Defence Force. He had a lot of misconceptions. I know he is a man with an open mind and will listen to the points of view that have been put not so much by me, because I am not the expert in these areas, but by the Chief of the Defence Force. I will quote a comment made by the Chief of the Defence Force when he and I and the Deputy Secretary A of the Department appeared before a parliamentary committee. On this issue of personnel wastage and its effect on the Defence Force, the Chief of the Defence Force stated:

SPEECH.PARA: On operational capability in the sense that there are ships, Army units or Air Force squadrons which have become operationally ineffective, it has not happened.

That has been reinforced by comments made prior to and after that time by the Chief of the General Staff, the Chief of Naval Staff and the Chief of Air Staff. I am not asking honourable members to accept my word on this issue. I am asking them to accept the word of the commanders in chief, who know the impact. When we look at the issue of wastage, there is no doubt that we have some problems, and I have raised that myself in the House. We are tackling the problems. The Dep Sec A, who has just visited the United Kingdom, was telling me that many other countries, particularly the United States and the United Kingdom--

TALK.START.PARA: —Dep Sec A-what does that mean?

—In the Defence Force we have a lot of jargon, I am afraid. We abbreviate everything. The leaders of my Department have had a look at what is going on in the rest of the world with the wastage problem. Unfortunately, it is not unique to our Defence Force. The problem of pilot shortage is happening to every defence force in the world, including the Soviet's. We have come up with a whole package of policies to deal with the issue. Not one of them by itself is going to solve the problem but we are tackling it.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest separation figures I have indicate that we may be turning the corner. Today I had a discussion with the Chief of Air Staff on the pilot issue. He thinks we have turned the corner with the availability of instructors, and I think that is a very good sign. There is no doubt that there are still problems but we are dealing with them. The way out is not the way honourable members opposite suggest-that is, to pay pilots what they can get in the commercial sector. That is not possible and we have to look to many other areas, including conditions of service. Honourable members will be pleased to note the rather large increase our pilots recently received in the flying allowance determination that was brought down recently.

I do not want to say much more about that, except to clarify another issue that was raised, that is, the amount of expenditure on defence. As honourable members know, I referred earlier to the fact that expenditure was almost $8 billion. I talked about the percentage of Commonwealth Government expenditure going to defence being almost 10 per cent. One of the other points raised related to the proportion of gross domestic product (GDP). The honourable member for McPherson has made much of the fact that defence expenditure presently represents some 2.4 per cent of GDP.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are your figures.

—They are our figures but as the Defence Force is very much aware-unlike the honourable member for McPherson-2.4 per cent of a Hawke-Keating level of GDP buys a lot more defence than a higher proportion of an inevitably smaller and rubbery Howard GDP. That is a very important factor that the defence forces of Australia understand.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the points I want to conclude on is the issue of morale in the Defence Force. I again congratulate those members of the Opposition, including the honourable member for Berowra and the honourable member for Macquarie, who paid tribute to the Defence Force. I know that that was endorsed by the honourable member for Herbert and the honourable member Isaacs in their own ways in their own electorates.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Maribyrnong?

—The honourable member for Maribyrnong has a very important defence science and technology organisation in his electorate and I know he is thrilled to have it there. The issue I want to talk about relates to morale in the Defence Force. Two members of the Opposition and members of the Government have paid tribute to the Defence Force for its contribution to the air show and to the naval salute. These are obvious ways in which the defence forces put on a fantastic exhibition of their skills and abilities for the people of Australia and the world. It is important that this chamber recognise the contribution they make, not just in those big things but in so many of the little things that they do throughout this country-the way they support the civilian infrastructure and the way they demonstrate, for example, by their tours of duty in the Pacific, the importance of our relations in the Pacific region. They make a magnificent contribution to the defence of this country. It is about time that greater recognition was given to that by the Opposition and that we had more positive policies. As I have said, morale is very important. I refer to an article which appeared in a defence supplement to the Australian newspaper recently. I wish to read from parts of an article by the Chief of the Defence Force because it has an important message for this chamber. His article, which was entitled `Unchecked criticism potentially damaging', stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has a coherent defence policy, an efficient and effective Defence Force and skilled Service professionals in whom Australians can feel pride and confidence.
Yet it has become fashionable in some small but vocal segments of the community to talk about the rundown of the ADF and our defences in general.
Both propositions are demonstrably untrue.
Unchecked, they are potentially damaging and run the risk of causing Australians to lose confidence in the ADF.
Such propositions are also depressing for the ADF itself which knows that reality is otherwise.

Before honourable members criticise the Defence Force-as the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) does consistently-I urge them to think about how important the morale issue is. I conclude by quoting, again, not myself but a person who came to this country to write an article in a very respected American magazine called Defence and Foreign Affairs. Greg Copely, the magazine's editor, did a number of interviews and analyses on defence policy in this country. I quote from a collection of articles appearing in that edition because I think that will set our defence policy in context:

Basically, what has happened is that the missions have been defined, at last, after years of indecision, and the forces are being structured to meet the challenges they face. This has engendered a strong and growing sense of purpose, and armed forces morale is on the rise again. Deployment and equipment has changed. And, most importantly, the Australian Defence Forces are being geared for the first time to fight as a cohesive unit . . .
I did not say that and the Minister for Defence did not say it; those were the comments of independent observer Greg Copely on the Australian Defence Force.

Before concluding I wish to pay tribute to a few people. One does not get a chance to do that very often. Obviously, I pay tribute to my colleague the Minister for Defence, who has set the parameters for defence well into the next century. More importantly-I am sure that he will not mind my saying that-I pay tribute to the men and women of the Defence Force, who give us enormous support. I also pay tribute to those who are not recognised very often; that is, the civilians who work for us in the Defence Department, who also give us a great deal of support. I thank all those who have taken part in this debate, particularly those who have made constructive comments, and I look forward to their continuing interest in defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up the Committee's time at any great length because I could not possibly provide a summing-up as effective as the one just given by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). Since she has handed out bouquets, I will hand her one. SPEECH.PARA: I was a little surprised that in this debate so little of the detail of the defence budget received any form of systematic attention. I found it quite odd that the Opposition spokesman on defence-the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White)-did not take the opportunity of bringing forward a matter of public importance on the subject, which was an option available to him.
