It is an issue that is worthy of the attention of this chamber. Even in 10 minutes there is a capacity to say something quite useful about it if one sets one's mind to it. No attempt was made by the Opposition spokesman to set his mind to it.

I noticed that the Opposition spokesman was heckling the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel along the lines that it was criticism of us that had marked the statements that he has made in public, not of the defence Services themselves. I would agree that in general the statements he produces are critical of us. That is a fairly legitimate role. But it is a fact, as he will no doubt be aware of now, that on a number of occasions he has crossed the line in a number of ways-and, I might say, quite inaccurately-and that has seriously worried some sections of the defence forces. For example, he commented recently that, effectively, the Royal Australian Air Force was totally ineffective when it was in the process, through the F111 reconnaissance team, of creaming international competition on reconnaissance all over the United States-winning the competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must be joking.

—It is not a joke: it is a fact. The honourable member treats it as a joke, but it happens to be a fact, nevertheless. The honourable member has become something of a pathetic figure as he drifts around from base to base spouting one promise after another, unattached to any policy and unattached to any notion of funding. The question of funds came up in the course of the discussion and that was a legitimate point to raise in the defence debate. I think that one of the honourable members opposite raised that point for discussion. It is a matter of some pride in this defence budget that in a budget in which there has been yet again, for about the third year running, a real reduction in total outlays, there is in fact a 0.5 per cent real increase in the defence vote.
—What about the White Paper?

—I will get on to that in a minute. In government there are always many competing functions for outlays. The Australian Labor Party is criticised frequently, and has been over the years, for tending to give less of a priority to defence than it does to social security. It must be said that any fair analysis of this Government's expenditure patterns, given the sorts of problems we have confronted, would reveal that it is other areas that have borne the brunt of those cuts-not defence. It is a rather easy position to defend, in our framework, because we have a coherent policy associated with it and that has not been in place before. We as a government have made a commitment to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McPherson asked about the White Paper. If he had read the White Paper he would have noticed that it is not predicated on 3 per cent real growth--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it was.

—No, it is not. The honourable member should read it. It was never predicated on 3 per cent real growth. It was predicated on an assumption that there would be some real growth over the life of the program but that we could not count on a substantial amount. In our historical experience that was the case. Therefore, the defence vote would need to be paid for essentially by the vigorous nature of planning and by rigorous activity in terms of cost efficiencies: the combination of the two would provide the wherewithal. That is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: Any delays that are occurring in major equipment projects-in fact, there are not many, as indicated by the honourable member and, as I said, we have been much more substantially on time in the way in which our procurement programs have proceeded than any other government before us, including Labor governments-in very large measure have been a result of the changed basis on which we do defence procurement in this country now. The fact is that very substantially we are becoming the leading input into the development of the heavy engineering and electronics industry in this country. The massive shift that is taking place away from overseas procurement into the industries that support our defence program inside this country is imposing very substantial strains on industry capacity to absorb it and its ability to go through the learning curve fast in order to be able to bring programs in on time. Even with all that, those companies in the main are keeping up with the procurement.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't put them to the test.

—They have been put to a pretty good test now, old son. We are now saving, effectively as a result of the reforms we have instituted in the factories, roughly the equivalent of 2 to 3 per cent real growth in the defence vote. I pay a very substantial tribute here to the trade union movement which has done this, in the main, quietly in consultation with us. When I took over this portfolio some 15,000 people were employed in the defence factories. The factories are now more productive, not only in real terms but also in aggregate terms, and are operating with about eight and a half thousand people. Of itself, this is by no means a measure of which one is proud, except that it constitutes an indication of efficiencies. That has occurred over a period of some four years. Enormous efficiencies have been achieved in those factories. There have been enormous reforms in industrial practices. They have all been done very quietly and all have produced a result which is enabling us, in very tight fiscal circumstances, to keep the equipment vote on track. I think that a great deal of tribute needs to be paid to the trade union movement for doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: The armed services and the general organisation of the Department of Defence is the next area of challenge. We have identified over $100m worth of savings that we believe can effectively be made in the logistics area. There will be some considerable pain in getting to that position. However, if we are to keep this defence budget on track those sorts of efficiencies are absolutely necessary. It is no good the Opposition coming into this place and telling us that we ought to spend more. It does not really matter what the Opposition says if, when it comes through with its policy-which I suppose it will do as soon as the honourable member for McPherson stops asking for more money that will not be delivered-it is predicated on substantial real increases, as was the Opposition's 1976 White Paper and Fraser's 1980 statement. If it is, we will know that we are being presented with a picture of failure. It simply will not be achieved. This is not a country that will be able to sustain massive growth in outlays over the next few years. That is all there is to it. It does not matter what anybody says. It does not matter if the Opposition comes in here and promises an aircraft carrier for helicopters. It does not matter if it comes in here and promises in-flight refuelling for the F111s. It does not matter if it comes in here and promises a plethora of other activities in relation to service conditions or benefits; it will not be done. If we lose office it simply will not be done. That is now understood in the defence forces. That is understood whether one addresses personnel at the Joint Services Staff College or talks to the people in the field; they do not expect any substantial or massive increases in the defence outlay. What they are into these days is reorganising themselves effectively. They are to be congratulated on that.

Those are the issues. Some of them were indeed raised in the Budget debate and were appropriate for canvassing in that debate. This is not an appropriate debate for the general discussion of foreign policy issues associated with defence. To those honourable members who participated in the debate in the appropriate way, I express grateful thanks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know where the honourable member for Blaxland, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), is tonight. I have heard that he actually visited Bankstown today for the first time in about five years.
—Order! The honourable member might address the matter before the Chair, which is the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988.

—I doubt it. Apparently, the Treasurer has been in Sydney all day and I am just hoping that--
—Order! The honourable member might get to the matter before the House.

—I was hoping that the Treasurer would be here to hear my contribution to the debate on the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill, because he has been very much involved in the heavy-handed way it has affected particular States. He has imposed a payroll tax on Commonwealth instrumentalities that have not been paying it in the States. He has made the States agents for the Commonwealth. The States are to keep only 10 per cent of the revenue collected; the rest is to be passed back to the Commonwealth. Unfortunately, the States get very little out of it. That is just one aspect of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect is the Bill's main facet for the States-the global borrowing limits that have been imposed by the Treasurer. That is why I would like to see him in the House. If the people of Australia read this legislation, they will see that, for the first time, the draftsmen and the Treasury have set themselves up as a law unto themselves and have placed themselves in a position where they will be able to make a decision as to how much the States, and individual States, can borrow without referring these borrowings back to the Parliament. The Bill states in no uncertain terms that the Treasurer has the final say as to the overall amount that the States can borrow.

We in the great electorate of Maranoa, in Queensland, are very concerned about the reduction of $367m-minus 31 per cent-which is by far the highest reduction of any of the States. When the Loan Council conference was on, New South Wales was Labor held. Of course, the Liberal Party and the National Party had a fantastic electoral victory in New South Wales. But that State has since suffered only a 5 per cent reduction. Western Australia actually had an increase of one per cent. The grant to the Northern Territory went up substantially, although its borrowings are quite low. As I said, Queensland has had a reduction of $367.7m-to a limit of $792.8m. The previous year it was able to borrow $1.16 billion. Queensland is a young, vigorous and developing State with all sorts of new projects under way, particularly in tourism and all the infrastructure that is needed for the new businesses being established. It has to borrow the funds to put railways, roads, et cetera, in place. But the Treasurer has come up with this Bill, which was rejected by the Premier at the Premiers Conference, not because Queensland did not want limits on borrowings, but because of the arbitrary reduction to which this centralist Labor Government has forced the States to agree. This legislation is being put through this House tonight to put that into effect. There has been a threat to the States that for every dollar they borrow next year over the global limit set by the honourable member for Blaxland, the Treasurer, the Government will reduce their grants by a dollar. That is the sort of government we have in this nation, and I think it is an absolute disgrace. I wish the Treasurer were here to answer my accusations.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's launching his book.

—We know he has been away, but I hope he comes back. He has been to his electorate for the first time in about five years, as well as being away on all his trips around the world. This legislation reduces the payments to the States, and if their borrowing limits are exceeded next year they will be penalised for every dollar they borrow. The legislation says that the States have no legal recourse on the basis of evidence or fact. In other words, the Treasurer can decide that a State has borrowed too much money and he is then in a position to say, `I shall impose a penalty upon it'. I should have thought that such a system would be against the Constitution, because that deems that the States must be governed independently and be able to do what they like as far as borrowings and all other transactions are concerned, without the Commonwealth imposing these sorts of sanctions on them.

SPEECH.PARA: The other ramification of this legislation is that since 1935 there has always been a gentlemen's agreement that guidelines be set down at the yearly conference and that the States would not go outside certain borrowing parameters. Unfortunately this agreement has been broken and this Bill sets in place the sort of legislation that I do not believe this nation needs. The legislation gives absolute discretion to the Commonwealth Treasurer. Clause 7 (1) (b) requires only that the Treasurer form an `opinion' that borrowing limits have been exceeded. Once he forms that opinion he can tell the States that they are going to get a substantial reduction in their grants.

Of course, the States rely very heavily on the grants. Over $12 billion is involved in this Bill and each of the States receives its grant on a per capita basis. This has also been altered by the Treasury. We see now that no leeway is given to the developing States of Queensland, Western Australia and Northern Territory, whereas previously, because they were developing States, they were allowed some extra borrowings and extra grants. We are now back to the old formula that was in place before World War II, where the golden triangle gets all the money and the rest of Australia gets the leftovers. The same thing has happened to local government. The same criteria are being used. The Government tied local government finance to the States grants arrangement. As these grants have been reduced we have seen a substantial reduction to grants to local governments, which are struggling to maintain the road structures and other infrastructures that are their responsibility. We have not seen any real increase in road funding since 1982. That has remained at about $1.2 billion for nearly six years. Other taxation Bills will come through this House tonight which will show that the trend continues away from the productive areas of this nation into the non-productive areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you speak on those Bills too?
—My word I will.
—I want to hear your views on them.

—My word the honourable member will hear them. Mr Acting Speaker, you will know that this Labor Government continues to increase taxation and to give those funds to the non-productive sector. Any sector showing a little productivity has its tax incentives-which were put in place by previous governments to help them expand their economies-reduced. We all wait with bated breath for tomorrow's balance of payment figures. No doubt we will, yet again unfortunately, see a substantial deficit figure relating to exports and imports, with exports being way down on what the Liberal and National Party Government was able to put in place and keep in place for 30 or 40 years of prosperity in this country. Under Labor, under the sort of exercise we are seeing with these Bills, the States are being starved of funds and even borrowings. They are not getting the grants they need so they need to borrow funds. They are being told by the Treasurer that they cannot have the money. He says, `If you borrow more than I tell you you can, you will have your grants reduced'.

SPEECH.PARA: In effect the Treasurer is setting himself up as prosecutor, judge, jury and hangman, because this legislation gives him the power to act solely on the basis of his opinion. It is clear that we will no longer have general revenue grants, but conditional grants based on compliance with the Commonwealth's wishes. This is the centralisation trend we have seen since the Labor Government has been in office.

At the back of the Bill are the determinations made under the Act. It mentions the Treasurer, and of course it includes some education grants. It mentions the Health Minister in relation to separate hospital funding, and it mentions the Australian Statistician-how on earth did he get into the act-and the sort of power he would have to determine just what the States should get, and it states:
. . . shall, for the purposes of this Act, be conclusively presumed to be correct.

In other words the States have absolutely no recourse to any court in the land. They cannot appeal to the High Court if they feel they are being unjustly dealt with by the Treasurer. That is the position we are in. I think that the Bill and all that is contained in it is an absolute disgrace. I hope that we do not see any other similar Acts come through this House. Although I support the amendment put before the House, I am not very keen on supporting the legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1988[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1988MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 concurrently with the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1988 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills we are debating tonight are the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Income Tax Amendment Bill and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. The coalition parties will not be opposing these Bills. However, I will be moving a second reading amendment highlighting a number of changes that typify this Government's high taxation policies. My colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) will also be moving a second reading amendment highlighting the completely unsatisfactory nature of the Government's health care policies. In addition, I will be moving committee stage amendments to clause 13 and two other related clauses of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) in an attempt to stop what we consider a gross case of retrospective abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is an omnibus Bill which seeks to implement a multitude of changes previously announced in this year's May statement and elsewhere. I will be mentioning tonight a number of points about some of these changes. However, first I wish to deal with the introduction of a tax on non-cash business benefits. This Bill seeks to implement, subject to what the Government calls `minor variations', the proposal which was announced on 4 February 1985 to tax non-cash business benefits. I have heard of government by press release, but to get the legislation 3 1/2 years after the press release is issued is ludicrous, to put it mildly. I will deal with that in greater detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't want to rush it through.

—The honourable member for Robertson is one of the better merchants in the Parliament. If he were giving a reward to members of his staff for the number of suits they sold on his behalf-namely, an air ticket around the world-and he read the press release 3 1/2 years ago and sought to change the prize or the award to his top salesmen, he could well find that as a consequence of waiting 3 1/2 years for the precise legislation allegedly to reflect the generality of the press release he could be a tax avoider today. So he ought not to be quite as agitated, in the friendly and respectful manner that he normally is, as he was tonight.
—I don't know whether I'm being insulted or not.

—The honourable member has been insulted by experts. I am only playing with him tonight. As the explanatory memorandum of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to this Bill explains, the proposal was announced to overcome practices that became prevalent following the decision in the full Federal Court in the Commissioner of Taxation v. Cooke and Sherden concerning non-transferable overseas trips given to some soft drink vendors under a sales incentive scheme sponsored by the manufacturer. The Court held that the existing law taxes non-cash business benefits only if the benefits are convertible to cash and are in the nature of income according to ordinary concepts. The overseas trip, being non-transferable, was not convertible to cash and the Court accordingly held that it was not subject to tax under any provision of the law. It was a fairly frequent occurrence, and still is, for such persons, such vendors, to be rewarded with a non-convertible benefit. That, however, will be taxed from now on because this Bill will tax non-convertible benefits provided after 4 February 1985 in basically the same way as benefits which are convertible into cash are taxable under the existing law if they are in the nature of income.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that a 3 1/2-year delay in legislating announcements is, with great respect to those who represent the Treasurer here tonight, an outrage. It is just not right that a short press release advising of a change in the law ought to be operable as the law. One does not need to be a practitioner to understand that if we say to people, `We are changing the law' and wait 3 1/2 years to bring in the legislation, we will unquestionably catch in the net people whose accountants and tax advisers will say, `We had better try to plan for this'. But they may get it wrong, because the generality of a press release is nothing to a piece of legislation.

I think it is an outrage and it ought not simply to be highlighted in a speech by someone leading on behalf of the Opposition; it ought be be expunged from this piece of legislation. That is why I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage. It is bringing government by press release to ridiculous heights. We therefore believe it would be extremely inequitable for the legislation to apply retrospectively. The legislation should apply only to benefits provided on or after the day of introduction of this Bill. That day, of course, was 31 August 1988.

There are a number of other points to raise in support of this position. The first is that the 4 February 1985 press release simply did not provide sufficient detail on the application of the future legislation. The press release clearly did not give taxpayers much indication of how affected benefits would be valued. The announcement merely stated, `As a general rule the value to be taxed will be the amount which the benefit would have cost the taxpayer in an arm's length transaction'. Taxpayers could reasonably have expected that detailed valuation rules would apply to the benefits from the date on which they were announced, not from some date 3 1/2 years ago.

As members of this House are aware, and as those residing in my State are aware, there is a commercial running for a very progressive bank in the State of Victoria called the State Savings Bank. It runs an advertisement talking about the advantages of banking with it. This ad runs on television in Victoria with a rather attractive young lady talking to her husband about the desire to withdraw funds from a particular account. When her husband seeks to explain that there are some difficulties with this, she simply looks at him and says, `But it is your money, Ralph. It is your money'.

I feel within my bones that there is a welling up within the Australian community which is about to give voice to all those who sit on the Government side of the House, and, dare I say, with the greatest respect to those who work with the Commissioner of Taxation, that when the Commissioner and when the Government demands this and demands that the Australian people will be justified in reminding that Government that `it is their money, Ralph; it is their money'. They earned it. Hawke did not earn it; Keating did not earn it; the Tax Commissioner did not earn it; they earned it. They elect governments basically within the confines of this country for two basic reasons. I leave aside security and foreign policy. They elect governments firstly to seek to improve their living standards and give them just a little more in the kick-as we grow and develop in this nation. Secondly, they elect them to run the economy efficiently. They do not elect governments to try at every turn to find more ways of taking their money from them, because it is their money, not the Minister's, not the Prime Minister's and not the Treasurer's. Of course, they ask of the government that much be funded for their and the nation's benefit, but they are reaching the point whereby they will say, `We want you to do this, but remember, you are doing it with our money'.

When the Government introduces legislation that is the legal inscription of a short press release and is to operate from the date of the press release and not the date of the legislation, it is saying it can put out in the press boxes of this building a generalised statement and then take 3 1/2 years to draft the legislation and impose a penalty retrospective for that full 3 1/2 years because it simply did not get off its `dots' early enough to advise people where they ought to be investing, what they ought to be doing with their money, or how they should be the recipients of particular awards. That is not right. The Government knows it is not fair. It breaches that element of tax principle of equity in taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that expression is unparliamentary.

—The honourable member for Maribyrnong has been a hard-working member of the community. I do not agree with much that he does in this House but he has either recently become or is soon to become learned in the law-is that not so?
—He has been learned in the law for many years.
—I am sorry, he had not given any wordy evidence of it in this place. I thought it was only coming upon him now and I apologise to him for that.
—He wants a job in Cabinet, but he does not have the numbers.

—He has not got the numbers, but I am talking about more intellectual pursuits than the grubby dealing in pursuit of numbers that he engages in. But he knows, as one who speaks on these matters from time to time, that equity is basic to the application of taxation. It is a basic principle. I do not want to dwell on it too long tonight, as I will be moving an amendment tomorrow in committee. It is just not right. The honourable member, instead of beavering around to get on every second-rate radio program for publicity, would do much better for himself and the members of his constituency if he would plead with his colleagues tomorrow to support my amendment and not enshrine retrospectivity as it flows through this element of the legislation. He will go off content tonight. He supports the greatest football club that ever pulled off a jersey in the State of Victoria.
—Hawthorn.

—He supports the Essendon Football Club. It therefore means he comes to a debate like this with clean hands. It means that he can think objectively about matters. I ask him tonight to go to his colleagues and say that the Opposition on this point is right; that we should apply the law from the date on which the legislation was introduced and not the date that the Grim Reaper, in the guise of the current Treasurer, issued a press release.

SPEECH.PARA: I said before that, because of the lack of valuation rules in the announcement of that press release and the expectation that detailed valuation rules would be announced, taxpayers could not know how to make provision for an unknown tax liability that would eventually arise. If their calculations were based on the valuations used for the purpose of analogous tax legislation such as section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, or the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act provisions, they would in almost all cases have underestimated their apparent tax liability under this Bill, and they will suffer.

The February 1985 press release failed to provide taxpayers with sufficient certainty to enable them to estimate their tax liabilities accurately. Under the proposed legislation, benefits must be valued, broadly speaking, at the amount the recipient would have had to pay to obtain the benefit in an arm's length transaction. Therefore, to determine the taxable value of benefits received over the previous 3 1/2 years, taxpayers will have to ascertain the amount they would have to pay to obtain those benefits at the time each benefit was granted. That is one hell of an administrative nightmare.

At one end this Government has ensured that the rich become super-rich; at the other end, quite properly, it has looked after the poor. But the overwhelming majority, the great bulk of this Australian community, is enshrined between those two groups. They are the ones who are being hit. In this instance people such as shop assistants, Avon ladies, Tupperware sellers-small businesses in which incentive schemes are run, such as giving trips; you name it-are the ones who will be obliged to pay tax on all of those benefits of the last 3 1/2 years. They will have to pay it in one lump sum. It is just not fair because it could tally to many thousands of dollars for some individuals. In many instances the hardship caused is likely to be extreme.

There are further cases of retrospectivity. The February 1985 press release gave the impression that the proposed legislation would apply only to benefits that are not convertible into cash. Benefits that are convertible into cash are presently valued at the amount for which the benefit could have been disposed of. However, under the proposed legislation the benefit will have to be valued at the amount which the recipient could reasonably be expected to have had to pay to obtain the benefit. In all fairness, that can be considered retrospective.

Many other aspects of this legislation raise serious doubts as to its clarity. For example, the nature of the new non-cash business benefits tax is similar to the fringe benefits tax. It is quite conceivable that a benefit may be taxed first as a fringe benefit at the employer level and later be taxed as a non-cash benefit at the employee level. Do we have to wait upon the goodwill of the Commissioner of Taxation to give us a ruling before we know the tax circumstances under which businesses must operate? The fact is that this legislation appears both inadequate and retrospective. We have no problems with the principle involved in the tax; nevertheless, we simply will not abide its outrageous retrospectivity. As I said, I will move an amendment in the committee stage in line with this.

The Government and its Treasurer have a shameful record on government by press release. Month after month tax legislation passes through this House which stems from press releases of six months, a year or even 18 months ago. But 3 1/2 years is just not acceptable. It is an insult to this Parliament, it is an insult to the people and it is also a usurping of the primacy of the executive branch of government over this Parliament. It ought not be tolerated by the Parliament. The Parliament can take action on that matter tomorrow.

Three and a half years to produce about two pages of legislation-which is what it amounts to in the totality of this omnibus Bill-is just nonsense. The uncertainty that is its companion strikes down productive and efficient businesses, especially small businesses which run on tight margins. When the law is in place they cannot even be certain then of their position. Does the House remember that in the last sitting period a couple of weeks ago-this is indicative of this Government; it is quite extraordinary-the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) brought into this place 280 amendments to his corporations package dealing with the securities and exchange industry? He introduced legislation into the Parliament, came back a short time later and said, `I have some amendments'. There were a whole 280 of them. It was quite unbelievable. It takes a touch of exquisite genius to introduce legislation in this Parliament, come back a week or so later and say, `Hang on a flash, we made a few mistakes here. I want to amend my own Bill'. There were 280 amendments. It broke all-time records. When one takes that example together with a 3 1/2-year wait for two pages of legislation to be introduced in the Parliament, one can see a sloppiness evident.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very sloppy.

—Very sloppy, and it is indicative of an arrogant government that is out of touch with the needs of average Australians. It could not care less. It introduces 280 amendments to a Bill in one case and, in another allows 3 1/2 years to pass until we can consider a couple of pages of legislation. It says, `Who cares? It's only the people we're dealing with. We'll fool them. We'll keep coming in here every day, saying that we're the greatest government in the history of this nation, saying that the mob on the other side is hopeless. They'll believe us'. I say to the Government members that the people have woken up to that rubbish. They will not believe it any longer. Every time that the Government has tested its support this year in by-elections, it has been rejected. As recently as last Saturday week it was rejected. There was the biggest swing against the Government ever recorded in the history of the seat of Oxley. The people are awake to the frauds and phoneys who try to slip this sort of stuff past them. They will not tolerate it. That is why we will produce the sort of amendments to which I have referred. Will this Government ever learn?

SPEECH.PARA: Many industry sources have told us on this side of the House that they do not think that the Treasurer will introduce legislation on his superannuation changes. My old mate the Grim Reaper has gone to his electorate to see the people. How did he travel to see the people tonight? He travelled in his white car. Why is he in his electorate tonight? Do honourable members know? Do they think that he is there to help a few of his constituents with their problems? He is in Canberra on weekends; he lives here. He is in his electorate to launch a book about himself. Modesty personified! He is back in his electorate for the first time since the election last year to launch a book which propagates the old Grim Reaper in print. I think he ought to think about that. As I said, industry sources have told us that they do not think the Treasurer will even introduce legislation on his superannuation changes. Does the House remember the superannuation changes referred to in the May statement? The Treasurer cannot work out the consequences. It will not affect his superannuation; he does not worry about that. He has his travel allowance and his trips overseas without a passport. There is no problem; he does not need to worry about that. TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha! Yes, maybe something on the Bill; you might talk about that.

—The honourable member has provided me with the opportunity to advise his constituents-because I will photocopy his interjection-that he laughed about retrospectivity and about the Treasurer's casual attitude to the superannuation schemes of his constituents. SPEECH.PARA: I return to other elements of the Bill. It will give effect to proposals announced in the May statement to withdraw certain special concessional arrangements for the write-off of capital expenditure on the cost of plant and equipment used for the purpose of producing assessable income. The general accelerated depreciation concessions allowing write-off of most plant and equipment over three or five years will be terminated and the special five years depreciation arrangement for storage facilities for hay, grain, fodder and primary production plant will be terminated. Some other depreciation allowances will be terminated. Along with the superannuation changes, these changes were also announced in the May statement, largely offsetting the 10 percentage point reduction in the company tax rate to 39 per cent. The Confederation of Australian Industry has already noted the irony that the now abolished 5/3 depreciation provisions were of particular benefit to the manufacturing sector at a time when increasing international competition necessitates shifts to more capital intensive production methods.

It is also worth noting that the depreciation changes will not necessarily benefit the many small businesses which are not incorporated and which still face high marginal tax rates. The Government often praises itself about its corporate tax reduction. The offsets that we see here certainly take the gloss off the Treasurer's rhetoric. The problem is that, at root, the Treasurer and the Government think too small. When the Treasurer claims to have reformed corporate tax in Australia and says that it now compares favourably with the average of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries, he misses the point. The point is that we have to do better than match the average. I am fed up, apart from the burden that Australians have to carry under the tax programs of this Treasurer, that he comes in and says as a matter of pride that we are now on a par with the average of OECD countries. If he really wanted this country to be the take-off nation in our part of the world, a take-off nation among the industrialised countries of the world, he would not compare it with an average! It is symptomatic of the thinking of this man.

We have to do better than match the average. We have to do much better. Even in our own region we have to compete with countries like Taiwan, Singapore and Korea. That is the relevant comparison, not some average blancmange within the OECD. The Treasurer works on rhetoric and illusion, and the flash answer of the day will do. The Treasurer comes into the House and buckets the Opposition. We have resisted doing that. I could come in here every day and say that the Treasurer is some piece of human pollution garbed in Italian decor. What does that add to the sum total of human knowledge? Nothing. So what is the point? The reality is that every time the Treasurer comes in here and tries to bucket the Leader of the Opposition, for example, he goes down another notch with the people. They do not want all this smart stuff. Anyone can do that. The Treasurer is not collecting all that money to come in here with some smart remark. I could come in here with a treatise of remarks on him if I wanted to, but I want to address the legislation and talk about where the nation is going and I want to provide some sort of blueprint in opposition to that Government. I do not want to come in here and say that the Treasurer has all the appeal of a wet sock. What does that amount to? Nothing.

What I want from this man, and from the Government, is for him to say: `I will not compare this nation with just the average of the OECD. I will try to give incentives to people to improve their lot and that of their families. I will get our economic house in order. I will cut expenditure. I will not allow the dole to be paid without something being given in return. I will seek to get tax rates down to provide incentive, so that people will have an incentive to invest and to work. I want to improve the lot of my people and the standing of my country so that at the end of any year they will not be hassling around with pieces of paper to see whether they are abiding by some retrospective piece of law. The will be able to pay their taxes with ease, the nation will be developed, and we will be participating within our region as a competitive force'.

One does not come into this place and hear the Treasurer talk about Australia. He does not address it. He is not interested in you or the people outside. He is interested in himself and his mates and the rhetoric that he can produce. That is what will bring him down. Tomorrow the Opposition will press these issues with great force.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been on the starting blocks itching to go, enjoying the presentation from the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the shadow Treasurer. Interestingly, I did interject, and I hope that the shadow Treasurer decides to write to all my constituents, because that will help my electoral prospects. I invite him to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: In the honourable member's 30-minute dissertation on this rather complex set of cognate Bills covering three areas, I timed his remarks. He spoke in substance on the legislation for about six of those 30 minutes. During the other 24 minutes honourable members heard about the legal qualifications of the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths); we heard about the suits of the Treasurer (Mr Keating); and we heard about the Essendon Football Club-that is fair enough, but there are others that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition might have given attention to. And so on. When he got to the substance, at the end of his contribution, he talked about the desperate need for some leadership and a blueprint, and I know that what he is saying in respect of his position is correct. The reason his contribution on the legislation was so lacking in substance and the reason he therefore had to fill in 30 minutes of the Parliament's time with all this other stuff is that there is no leadership and there is no concept of a blueprint or a policy on where these things ought to be going. For the first few minutes of my contribution I shall talk about some aspects of this legislation that were not touched on by the shadow Treasurer in his opening remarks. In that process I will come to the question of, as he described it, government by press release and the question of retrospectivity. I am happy to address that matter in the context of this legislation.

Let me go first of all to the Bills-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), the Income Tax Amendment Bill and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. One of the areas that the shadow Treasurer did touch upon was his concern about the 5/3 depreciation changes. Before we introduced this legislation a number of Government members met with people in industry and elsewhere, who put to us the view that there needed to be a major change in the treatment of depreciation and a rational approach. The approach that has been adopted in the legislation, as announced in the May statement by the Treasurer, is a shift to depreciation based on the effective life of capital plant. That means that investment can be based and depreciated claimed on real expectations instead of distorted investment patterns brought about by depreciation regimes designed to get people to buy certain products to suit a seasonal spending pattern. It is a far more rational approach and one which, to my knowledge, has been widely welcomed across industry.

It also gives us an opportunity to touch upon something else raised by the shadow Treasurer, showing an element of dishonesty in his approach to the Australian electorate in general. From the time these announcements were made--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not like that remark about an element of dishonesty and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Does it offend the honourable member?
—It offends the honourable member and I am sure it offends the person about whom it was said.
—It offends the honourable member for Bradfield and the House. Would the honourable member withdraw it.

—I am happy to withdraw it. The statements made were mendacious. Just after the May statement was brought down and the measures about the change in the company tax rates were mentioned, members of the Opposition, with the shadow Treasurer at the forefront, were running around Australia claiming that the Government was favouring big business by not giving tax cuts to workers but giving them to companies. They were the exact words of the shadow Treasurer. He proclaimed them everywhere. Now he comes into the House tonight and repeats something that the Treasurer made as clear as a bell when these policy changes were announced-that is, that there are going to be changes made, including depreciation changes, which will offset and make revenue neutral the change in the company tax. He has come in here tonight claiming that we have been hard on business. He cannot go out into the community and say that the Government favours business at the expense of workers and then come in here and say that the Government is dudding the business sector. Let us have an element of honesty about this. The measure he has complained about is a fair and sensible change which should have been made years ago. I have no problem in both explaining and supporting it in this debate tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Treasurer made no mention-I wonder why?-about a number of other aspects of this legislation. One is the increase provided for in the pensioner rebate. Pensioners will not be required to pay tax on extra income they earn, something that many of us were very pleased to see incorporated in the Budget and which came about as a result of a lot of consultation with pensioner groups. It is a change to ensure that many pensioners are removed from the tax net and also from the provisional tax net. It is legislated for, on the table, provided for in this House. Of course, that was not even touched upon by the shadow Treasurer. It is a major benefit to pensioners which the shadow Treasurer chose to ignore. Why? Because he, along with other members opposite, delights in wandering around Australia talking to pensioner groups and scaring them about all the dreadful things the Government is doing. But when legislation is introduced improving the position for pensioners, there is no mention of that at all.

Let me move to the question of non-cash business benefits. One of the other things evident to members studying this legislation is that part of it relates to policy changes and part of it is what I call the dog catching up with its tail as it chases it round the circle. The issue of non-cash business benefits is one of those aspects. One of the unfortunate aspects of corporate taxation in Australia is that we legislate for the specific. We are required, because of the way the tax legislation is structured, to lay down the things that will be treated as income. The minute we do that, out come the corporate lawyers and the fancy tax boys with the microscope, studying every word to try to find that little loophole. In this case they found a loophole because legislation cannot be drawn up to cover every single possibility. They went off with an appeal to the High Court of Australia and an element of Government revenue was lost because of this loophole approach. What this legislation does is to fix up that loophole and bring into the tax net another form of fringe benefit, another form of payola to the high-fliers-the old overseas trip that cannot be cashed out. It was to be expected that the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, representing business interests, would be complaining about that tonight.

Another element of the legislation which I particularly welcome is the liberalising of the remote area home ownership scheme that brings about a change in the treatment of homes in remote areas. This is something we had particular experience with on the Prime Minister's country task force. Moving around Australia and looking at aspects of the fringe benefits legislation and other forms of tax treatment, we came to see that this was an area that needed some tidying up, some liberalisation. I am glad to see that that has been incorporated in this legislation.

The statement made by the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) just before I was called upon to speak was very relevant to another aspect of this legislation that I want to touch on. Again, it is an area the shadow Treasurer chose not to speak about, despite the fact that it is one of the key areas he has focused on for a number of years. I refer to the Medicare levy. One of the provisions of the Bill is to put in place increases in thresholds so that the Medicare levy cuts in at a higher level of income or, in other words, gives further relief from the levy for people on lower levels of income. It does one other thing: it enshrines the rate for the Medicare levy at the same level. This means that it will have been at the same rate since December 1986. In other words, this legislation means that the Government has honoured its election commitment to maintain the Medicare levy at the present level-not to increase it, as Opposition members ran around during the election campaign saying would be done, but to maintain it as it is and to increase the salary cut-in point so that people on lower incomes will not be required to pay the levy. Of course, the shadow Treasurer chose to make no mention of that at all. As I said at the start of my contribution, his 30-minute dissertation in the House was full of a whole lot of stuff about football and Italian dressing styles and fashionwear and had very little to do with the substance of the legislation. He does not want to talk about the legislation. The Minister's statement means that another element has crept into this discussion about the levy.

Because the Government has chosen to defer this House's consideration of the tax file number legislation, the improvements relating to the Medicare levy will have to be deferred. One is entitled to ask, `Why are we deferring this legislation? Why is this benefit being deferred?'. The reason is that we are giving the Opposition more time to consider its position on the tax file number. By gee, when we come into this House with the tax file legislation we will see the Opposition fronting up to a tough one. Will it be prepared to be fair dinkum about backing these measures to give the Commissioner of Taxation some real tools to get into the secret bank accounts, the solicitors' secret trust funds and all the other areas where the high-fliers tuck their dough away? Will it be prepared to vote yes for the legislation? I hope so. We are deferring a benefit to be derived from improvements relating to the Medicare levy to give the Opposition the time that it has requested to consider the proposed amendments to the legislation. It will be very interesting to see the Opposition's response.

I go to the one matter of substance on which the shadow Treasurer spent some time; that is, the issue of Government by press release, as he called it, and the question of retrospectivity. I have a very clear position on this. I am not happy that legislation is delayed and takes quite some time to get on the table, but I am even less happy when nothing happens until a matter is put into the Parliament's legislative program. I point out that the legislative program is continually disrupted by the Opposition and continually blocked and mucked about by the Senate. That is the reason the legislative program gets behind, and that is the reason we take time to get legislation into and through the Parliament. We cannot just leave the people of Australia with no guidance and no direction on these issues while we have these problems in the House. I believe that the Treasurer's actions in issuing guidance and directions to the community through press releases and statements in the House are a means of outlining the position as it will apply from a certain date. So I reject what will obviously be a beat-up on the retrospectivity issue. I reject that notion.

Everyone who will be affected by this legislation has known from the time the Treasurer made the statement-as have all their corporate lawyers and fancy tax accountants who study this stuff in minutiae-exactly how and when their positions will be treated. Opposition members should not march in here and preach retrospectivity as some sort of evil notion in this context. If they intend to block the Government's legislative process, they must acknowledge that the only alternative we have is to make policy announcements and give outlines of the way matters will be treated. I think that that is a pretty positive way of going about things. I happen to have a personal view that the quicker we get away from legislation by the specific and get to a situation where, if the high-fliers want to try a fancy scheme in the hope that it will get through all the loopholes, they must place it on the board before the Tax Commissioner beforehand and get permission to do so, the better. That is the sort of direction in which I would like to see us going. The whole legislative process of tax law by loophole patching up which gets created by this system is one that, sooner or later, Australia must have some other thoughts about.

I do not have any problems with this legislation. I think that the Minister's explanation was a pretty good one. If the honourable member for Kooyong wants to use his parliamentary or shadow Minister's stamp allowance writing to all the electors in my constituency telling them about my position on this matter, he is welcome to do so. It will improve my margin. My constituents understand that the Government is prepared to make decisions, lay them out on the table and be judged by the results. The results are that Australia is back in the black; the tax laws have been cleaned up; the country is moving back into credit; and we are starting to raise our heads in international circles. The shadow Treasurer comes in here and talks about the OECD average. The OECD average is a very good guide for Australia because at the moment our economic performance and economic restructuring put us at the top of the list of OECD countries. That is something in which every Australian can take a lot of pride. It is not something that the Opposition can get any free credits out of.

In the time that I have been a member of this Parliament, every move that has been made by this Government to bring about reforms and to clean up all the rorts has been opposed on the other side of the House. Now, when there is some credit to be given and there is some recognition that we have turned a $9 billion deficit into a $5 billion surplus, what do we get? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition wanders in here saying that he would love to have some leadership and a blueprint. I am sure that he would. If he had a blueprint he could put it to the people and be judged on it. But he does not have one. All the policies and all the action come from the Government. All we get from the other side of the House is personal denigration and disruption of Question Time-all the personality stuff. It is simply a camouflage for the fact that there are no policies and there is no creative thinking on the other side of the House. I have no problem in supporting the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate the House is considering the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988, the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1988 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988. As Opposition spokesman on health in this place I intend to confine my remarks to the Medicare legislation. As a first step, I foreshadow an amendment which I will move at the appropriate time in this debate, which will probably be tomorrow morning. The amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) expresses its concern at the increasing costs of Medicare despite a fall in the delivery of medical services, particularly to the poor and needy;
(2) deplores changes made by the Government to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme; and
(3) calls on the Government to ensure that all Australians obtain the high-quality, affordable health care, to which they are entitled'.

The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1988 further amends the Medicare Levy Act 1986. It has been introduced to comply with the current requirement that legislation authorising the collection of the levy must be passed annually by the Parliament. In this respect I should point out that we have this annual opportunity to review the Medicare levy and the performance of Medicare because of the Opposition's amendment to the legislation some 12 months ago. It is certainly in no way due to any commitment on the part of this Government to the concept of open government. It was this side of the Parliament that successfully moved the amendment to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987 which ensured that the Government would be thwarted in its attempt to include authorisation of the collection of the levy for all future years. Failure to have secured our amendment-which did not happen-would have meant that the Parliament would have been obliged to legislate only for changes to the rate of the Medicare levy. It is welcoming to see that the Government has understood the reality in this respect and has brought forward the legislation in the form it is in.

In addition to authorising the collection of the Medicare levy, this Bill proposes to increase the taxable income threshold below which a full or partial exemption from the levy may be claimed. This is a move which brings these exemptions more into line with current day realities. Notwithstanding the fact that, courtesy of the amending statement tonight of the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris), this move has been deferred, it is a measure that is welcomed by the Opposition as it goes some way towards reducing the onerous taxation burden which this Government, over the past five years, has placed on low and middle income Australian families. However, less welcome is the fact that those same low and middle income Australian families are being short-changed by the Government in terms of the actual delivery of health care. While members of the Australian community are having regularly to fork out 1.25 per cent of taxable income for the Medicare levy, the return which they are in fact receiving for their health dollars is declining.

At this point in my contribution it is perhaps worth remembering that this is yet another of the broken promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who said that the Medicare levy would remain at the one per cent figure at which it was originally set. It is also worth remembering that at the time Medicare came into effect in 1984 we were told that it would be self-funding. Unfortunately, as in so many other areas, the claims made by the Government in support of Medicare have proved to be patently untrue. It is calculated that the 1.25 per cent of taxable income accounts for only 16 per cent of health care costs in the Commonwealth Budget. Medicare, hailed by the Labor Government as a panacea for all the problems confronting the sick, is and always has been a dismal failure.

What we have seen since this Government assumed office in 1983 is a massive growth in public health care costs. Australia's taxpayers are now footing the bill for a health Budget which is something like 70 per cent more than it was when Labor came to power. What are they getting in return? The answer is, precious little. I invite those honourable members in the chamber to cast their minds back to the days before the Hawke-Keating Government. I ask them: were there doctors' strikes in those days; were there nurses' strikes; and, importantly, were there queues of people waiting for hospital beds? Of course, the answer to all of these questions is no, there were none. We had no doctors' strikes; we had no nurses' strikes, and we certainly had no queues of at least 100,000 people waiting for hospital beds.

The great irony of Medicare and the current health care system is that as well as being tragic in human terms that such a dramatic downturn in the availability and quality of health should have occurred under a government which claims to have a mandate on social justice, it is also a system which disadvantages the very people it is supposed to assist. We have got a government at the moment which is not above posturing as the most caring and compassionate government in our history. Yet it is this very same government which is now rationing the provision of health care by means of the ever-lengthening queues for public hospital treatment. As a consequence of this, the quality of life of those pensioners who need cataracts removed or who need hip replacement surgery so that they can get around is being severely diminished.

These are the people who are the victims of a cruel hoax. They are the people who believed the Government's promise that it would provide a free and universal medical and hospital system and that they would be looked after in times of ill health. Instead, these pensioners and other people on low incomes find themselves at the bottom of the barrel, and at the end of the lengthening queues. They find themselves being treated as second class citizens and being forced to wait inordinate periods of time for much needed hospital treatment of their personal health problems. What is even more galling for them is that they know that while they are waiting for pain relieving surgery other people are jumping ahead of them in the hospital waiting list queues. Those people in our community who are more articulate, who can manipulate the hospital waiting lists or who can afford to pay for private health insurance and, subsequently, private treatment, are getting attention when they require it. All this is happening at a time when total government expenditure on health care is rising. As was pointed out on page 1 of the Health Care Markets policy discussion paper of the Consumers Health Forum of Australia released earlier this week:
. . . health care costs each year, on average, around $1,100 a head or around $3,000 a household.

This is a bill which, as far as the average person is concerned, is largely unseen. A summary of health outlays presented on page 122 of Budget Paper No. 1 1988-89 shows that in the current financial year the Government expects to spend in the order of $7,350.5m on medical and hospital services and benefits. This level of expenditure is quite clearly not matched by receipts from the Medicare levy. The figure for such receipts is listed on page 314 of Budget Paper No. 1 as a mere $2,315m, taking into account the new thresholds for low income earners as ultimately will be provided in the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. That figure for receipts is not even a third of the cost of items listed as medical and hospital services and benefits-all of which I assume represent the real cost of Medicare. As I said in this House in the debate last week on the appropriations for the Department of Community Services and Health, Medicare is a monster which is gobbling up ever increasing amounts of public funds. The cost containment methods being applied by the Government have not worked in the past and will certainly not work in the future.

The rationing of health care via the public hospital waiting list system has not significantly reduced costs. However, as I have already mentioned, it has significantly reduced the access of low income earners and the most disadvantaged to hospital treatment. This is something which the Opposition believes cannot and should not be tolerated in a society such as ours. We on this side of the House are committed to seeing all Australians receiving the quality health care to which they are entitled. What has the Government been doing? It has been casting around looking for scapegoats to blame for the failure of its unachievable promise to provide a free and universal medical and hospital system. It has sought to reduce services and costs by abolishing the Medicare rebate for some items. For example, last year it hacked away at the Medicare rebate for the removal of certain skin cancer treatments. That was a move which flew in the face of overwhelming evidence that the incidence of skin cancer in this country is one of the highest in the world, if not the highest.

This year we are being treated to a misguided attempt to contain costs by tinkering with pathology rebates and the provision of life saving drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In addition, moves within the Department of Community Services and Health itself to curtail expenditure on salaries are jeopardising a range of services. Take, for instance, the nutrition section of the Department, which employs dietitians to prepare scientifically based tables on the composition of foods. The information which the section collects and disseminates is invaluable to programs aimed at improving the nutrition and overall health of the Australian people. Yet, this section is faced with staff cuts which will virtually eliminate its scientific function and turn it instead into something like a propaganda machine for the Government's much touted Health for All Australians plan-although how this plan can be expected to work when its No. 2 priority, nutrition, is being lopped off at the knees in terms of scientifically based information, is hard to fathom.

Take also the Department's oral health unit, which on the evidence contained in the Budget Papers appears to have been left without any funds at all. The Government's action in abolishing the oral health unit was rightly internationally condemned by a unanimous resolution of the General Assembly of the Federation Dentaire Internationale meeting in Washington, D.C. last weekend. Again, it is interesting to note that the Health for All Australians document, so warmly endorsed by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) when he launched it on 7 April this year, identified dental disease as of `continuing concern'. In fact this document makes the point on page 52 that:
The contribution that dental health makes to total health is not well recognised.

Prophetic words indeed. Seemingly the Government, which has endorsed the recommendations contained in the document, does not recognise the contribution which dental health makes to total health. Otherwise, why would the Government abolish the oral health unit, leaving itself as the only government of a major country without a dental unit to advise it. In the absence of the expert consultant advice which the unit could provide, there might well be adverse consequences for dental public health as well as for the practice of dentistry in this country.

These two examples relating to the nutritional section and the oral health unit of the Department of Community Services and Health are just a couple of instances which clearly demonstrate this Government's misplaced priorities in the health area. In the mistaken belief that governments are the only bodies which can actually do things in the public policy area, this Government has blindly pursued an ideological path which has led it to be at loggerheads with health care professionals. Not only that, but its ideological commitment to publicly funded health care, as opposed to a more productive and rewarding mix of the public and private sectors, has diminished the quality and level of service in our overall health care system.

It has categorised private hospitals, which account for about 25 per cent of all Australian hospital beds, and subsequently replaced this with a categorisation of private hospital patients to align insurance benefits to the treatment received. These moves have not only affected Commonwealth bed subsidies for private hospital patients but have also impacted upon the level of benefits a privately insured patient attracts from a hospital insurance fund. As a result of its ideologically inspired attacks on the private health care sector, the Government has overloaded the public health care system to the point where Medicare is about to irretrievably break down.

The Medicare levy to be collected as a result of the passage of this legislation is nothing more, and nothing less, than a token gesture towards meeting a total health care budget which is exploring in its scope, a budget which, in the current financial year, is estimated to be nearly $11 billion dollars, compared with last year's figure of just over $8.2 billion-a sum which does not just exceed last year's budget by something equal to our current inflation rate of about 6 per cent, but which represents an increase in outlays of 30.3 per cent. In anyone's terms this is a very steep increase. If the Australian taxpayers were seeing value for their money, such an increase would be slightly more acceptable. But what we are seeing, and have already seen, under Medicare is a significant decline in the availability of health care delivered to the community in general, and the less well off sections of that community in particular. The Medicare levy collected as a result of the passage of this legislation will be but a drop in the bucket in terms of meeting the cost of what has proved to be an overly expensive experiment in socialised medicine.

The sooner the Government realises that Australians will have access to the high quality health care which they deserve only when there is an active partnership between the public and private health care sectors, the better off we will all be.

TALK.START.PARA: —It never ceases to amaze me how arrogantly certain Ministers in this Government treat the Australian people. SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has gone to great lengths to eliminate from public scrutiny the figures that may reflect poorly upon his Government. I refer to the Minister's decision to ban the release of Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) data showing unemployment levels on a town by town basis. I raised the matter earlier today in this place and again the Minister failed adequately to explain his motives for covering up an important local source of information.

There are two major sources of labour force statistics-the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and the CES figures. Until March this year a feature of the CES quarterly statistics publication was the inclusion of figures showing the number of unemployed people awaiting placement. The figures set the CES information apart from the ABS data, not because they were necessarily more accurate, but because they were the only labour force information detailed enough to provide an indication of the unemployment situation in a town, a suburb or a region. They gave information upon which local communities could gauge economic and employment trends and, if necessary, develop effective counter policies and plan the provision of support services.

I acknowledge that ABS data is a more accurate statistical representation of the labour force. But even a Government Minister, the former Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) recognised the value of CES figures in 1983. I quote from a press statement he released in July that year. He said:
The CES figures are a useful supplement because they provide a greater regional break up of unemployment than the ABS collection . . . they fill an important gap in local labour market information.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when he was Opposition spokesman on unemployment, quoted CES figures in a Sydney Morning Herald article in March 1981. He claimed that they were `clear evidence' of the prevailing labour force situation.

Obviously, the CES figures are less useful to members of the Government when they are unfavourable. That is demonstrated clearly in evidence I have received from the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Twice in 1987 the Western Australian Premier, Mr Dowding, when he was the Minister for Employment in the Burke Government, put pressure on the Federal Government to can the CES statistics. In certain parts of Western Australia where they were rightly being used to highlight the unemployment problem they were less than favourable. The Federal Minister Mr Dawkins, reacted by asking his Department to look into the matter. A minute to the Minister from the Deputy Secretary of the Department dated 2 September, makes interesting reading. It states:
Because of recent concerns about the CES figures we have been reviewing the current guidelines for the local release of CES data by CES managers . . .
The work was placed `on hold' during the election campaign on sensitivity grounds.

The minute went on to make certain recommendations, agreed to by Mr Dawkins, which allowed CES managers to continue to release the figures in a different format. But on 16 October Mr Dowding came back on the scene, complaining again about the release of Unemployed Awaiting Placement (UAP) figures. This time he presented evidence in the form of two newspaper articles. Where did those stories appear? Of course, in Collie and Albany-two politically sensitive electorates for the State Labor Government.

Again the Department looked into the matter. A recommendation came back to the then Minister for Employment Services, the present Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding), to allow the continued collection of the figures, but to allow CES managers, release them only upon request. Mr Holding agreed. Obviously under pressure from his Western Australia, colleague, Mr Dawkins overruled Mr Holding in January this year, and ordered that CES managers not be allowed to release local UAP data.

The banning of these figures has nothing to do with their accuracy. The actions of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, in cahoots with his friend Mr Dowding, were clearly politically motivated. The people of Australia have been duped again.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of the national opinion poll commissioned by his Department on the Child Support Scheme.
(2) What did this poll reveal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A national survey of 1,200 people (18 years and over) was conducted for the Department of Social Security late in April and early in May in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth by The Market Research Workshop and Quadrant Research Services. To reduce costs, the survey formed part of a wider, regular ``omnibus'' survey by Quadrant.
The cost of the survey was $23,287.50.
91% of respondents supported the Child Support Scheme's compulsory maintenance collection, 61% describing the scheme as ``a very good idea'' and 30% as ``quite a good idea''. Only 6% were opposed.
86% supported the collection of child maintenance by automatic deductions from the pay of the non-custodial parent. Only 2% were concerned about possible inconvenience for employers.
82% supported recent amendments to the Family Law Act under the Child Support Scheme increasing the levels of child maintenance ordered by the courts.
94% agreed that both parents should provide adequate financial support for their children after a marriage or relationship breaks down.
93% said the parents-and not the taxpayer who pays for Social Security pensions and benefits-should be responsible for supporting the children after a marriage or relationship breaks down.
79% supported the idea of custodial parents who receive an income-tested sole parent pension being asked to use the new child maintenance collection system (for some, this is now compulsory).
78% supported the present laws under which each parent's right of access to their children depends on what is considered best for the children and not on whether child maintenance is paid.

These very high levels of support for the Child Support Scheme were subsequently confirmed by an independent public attitude survey commissioned by the Sydney Morning Herald and the Age shortly after the Scheme began in June.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 1 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say which International Labour Organisation Conventions have been applied by France, Britain and the United States to the non-metropolitan territories in the Pacific for whose international relations they are responsible, including any trust territories for which they are the administering authority.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Constitution of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) establishes a mechanism under which a Member Country is obliged, subject to certain limited exceptions, to apply ILO Conventions which it ratifies to non-metropolitan territories for which it is responsible.
Article 35 (1) of the Constitution imposes the following obligation on Members:

``The Members undertake that conventions which they have ratified in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution shall be applied to the non-metropolitan territories for whose international relations they are responsible, including any trust territories for which they are the administering authority, except where the subject-matter of the Convention is within the self-governing powers of the territory or the Convention is inapplicable owing to the local conditions or subject to such modifications as may be necessary to adapt the Convention to local conditions.''

Under Article 35 (2), a Member is required to declare the extent to which it undertakes that the provisions of a Convention which it has ratified are to be applied to a non-metropolitan territory (except where the subject matter is within the self-governing powers of such a territory).
